notes_H3: Contact tracing is conducted on a statewide level, and is often further decentralized by county or local health departments or contracted out to private organizations. Not all states report their contact tracing statistics, so it is difficult to gauge the efficacy of contact tracing.     According to the CDC Covid-19 data dashboard, 8.25% of tests were positive over the past 7 days (as of April 14). As an example of contact tracing efforts, for the week of April 4, Oregon's contact tracers reached 84% of Covid-19 cases identified within a 24 hour period. Their goal is to reach 95% of cases. During the same timeframe, only 36.2% of positive cases were traced to a known source, and their goal is to trace at least 70% of cases to a known source.     Funds from the American Rescue Plan (signed into law March 11) are meant to provide technical assistance to states, municipalities, territories, and tribes to help trace and monitor the spread of Covid-19.     CDC: https://archive.vn/yvN69    Link to Plan text: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414214206/https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/1319/text    Link to Oregon data: https://web.archive.org/web/20210414221835/https://public.tableau.com/profile/oregon.health.authority.covid.19
notes_H6: whilst in many states regulations on facial coverings have been eased, in some states such as California facial coverings are still required in 'most settings outside the home'. There is often exemptions for young children.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504070227/https://www.aarp.org/health/healthy-living/info-2020/states-mask-mandates-coronavirus.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504065011/https://www.usatoday.com/storytelling/coronavirus-reopening-america-map/
notes_H7: Vaccine is now available for everyone over 16years.     Vaccines - Pfizer and Moderna    CDC Vaccination tracker - A total of 211,581,309vaccines have been administered  https://web.archive.org/web/20210421025151/https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations

name: Alaska
notes_C1: Original note by Erin Kanzig: Beginning April 12, Juneau’s middle and high school students will be returning to school four days a week. The change expands the in-person high school schedule by one day and the middle school schedule by two days. Wednesday will remain a distance-learning day at all levels. Students can choose to continue with remote distance learning if they wish.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210407192221/https://www.juneauempire.com/news/school-district-announces-expansion-of-in-person-learning/    Coding updated by Reviewer Monika Pyarali to reflect previous changes (see note on March 15)
notes_C2: Anchorage's Emergency Order 19 remains in effect as of April 7. All restaurants, bars, breweries, and night clubs can open at reduced capacity to maintain physical distancing. Indoor entertainment facilities, indoor gyms and fitness centers can also operated with reduced capacity (masks required). Establishments offering sit-down service of any kind must have visitor logs in order to assist with contact tracing. Employers must require employees to work from home if remote work is feasible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407193145/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/final%20signed%20eo19.pdf
notes_C3: Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Edit:    Coded changed to 1T (from 2T) according to Attachments C and D of Anchorage Emergency Order 20 (enacted 17 April 2021). Attachment C allows for entertainment facilities to open at a capacity that allows for six feet of physical distancing and other COVID-19 related safety measures. Attachment D allows for organized sports with similar stipulations for spectators.    Anchorage EO-20 (enacted 17 April 2021):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427202830/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/emergencyorder20-final-signed.pdf  Attachment C on entertainment venues:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427203849/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/eo-20%20attachment%20c%20-%20entertainment%2041221.pdf  Attachment D on organized sports:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210414174904/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/eo-20%20attachment%20d%20-%20organized%20sports%2041221%20230pm.pdf
notes_C4: On April 17, Anchorage will lift all limits on outdoor gathering with mask and social distancing measure still in effect. Restrictions on indoor gathering (~35 people) will still be in place.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210414200618/https://apnews.com/article/alaska-anchorage-coronavirus-pandemic-2d11a1668c1c3bd6f0dc6dd9bf39975f    https://web.archive.org/web/20210412225928/https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/anchorage/2021/04/12/read-the-full-text-of-anchorages-emergency-order-lifting-outdoor-gathering-limitations/
notes_C5: The People Mover in Anchorage continues to operate with safety measures in place, " People Mover and AnchorRIDES continue to operate regular service and rider limits remain at 14-riders per 40-foot bus and 6-riders per vehicle on the neighborhood routes with 22-foot buses. Cloth face coverings are still required to ride People Mover."     https://archive.vn/II4oD
notes_C6: Anchorage's EO-19 encourages people to avoid contact with those outside their household and to limit trips outside the home.    Health Advisory No. 1 also remains in effect statewide ("Minimize time indoors with individuals outside your household even if you can maintain a distance of six feet. Avoid all gatherings, even small ones, with persons who are not in your household.")     https://web.archive.org/web/20210407194808/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-1-Recommendations.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407193145/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/final%20signed%20eo19.pdf
notes_C7: Health Advisory No. 3 remains in effect (first issued Feb 14), which provides guidance on intrastate travel, including recommending testing, physical distancing, and quarantining as necessary both on and off the Road System and Alaska Marine Highway System. "Anyone who is currently infected with SARS-CoV-2 virus must not travel until they are cleared from isolation by a medical professional."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410204530/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-3-Intrastate-Travel.pdf
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: Unemployment assistance is available. The Division of Public Assistance lists other resources available to Alaskans on their website.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410211043/https://labor.alaska.gov/COVID-19-programs.htm    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410211545/https://cse.google.com/cse.js?cx=c0fe050eb6ce15f1d
notes_E2: There are no active statewide moratoriums or suspensions of utility shutoffs. The CDC eviction moratorium is in effect. Those who qualified for the rental assistance program (applications closed March 5) will have access to 12 months of rental assistance.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410211545/https://cse.google.com/cse.js?cx=c0fe050eb6ce15f1d    https://web.archive.org/web/20210410213801/https://www.muni.org/Departments/Mayor/PressReleases/Pages/Municipality-of-Anchorage,-Cook-Inlet-Housing-Authority-partner-with-Alaska-Housing-to-distribute-up-to-12-months-of-rent-a.aspx
notes_H1: The public continues to be informed about Covid-19, vaccination and testing, etc. As an example:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210410215810/https://public.govdelivery.com/assets/Signup.js
notes_H2: COVID-19 testing is widely available to the public.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210410220041/https://coronavirus-response-alaska-dhss.hub.arcgis.com/app/2d92b77bc8044329a1ee3954b063bd8c
notes_H3: Alaska has a contact tracing program, though it is not clear how thorough it is.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210322232305/https://cse.google.com/cse.js?cx=c0fe050eb6ce15f1d
notes_H6: Anchorage's Executive Order 13 v4 remains in effect, face coverings are required in all public spaces. Alaskans are generally encouraged to follow CDC guidance and wear masks under Health Advisory 1, which was issued February 14 and remains in effect until rescinded.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210407194051/https://www.muni.org/covid-19/documents/eo13v4.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210407194808/https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/02.14.21-Health-Advisory-1-Recommendations.pdf
notes_H7: Alaska resumes administration of Johnson & Johnson vaccines following FDA and CDC approval after a temporary pause.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426171725/https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/2021/04/23/alaska-providers-receive-green-light-to-resume-use-of-single-dose-covid-19-vaccine-after-federal-guidance/

name: Alabama
notes_C1: http://web.archive.org/web/web/20210503185828/https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2021/04/Safer-Apart-Order-Final-4.6.21.pdf
notes_C2: As of April 27th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426140506/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426042602/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html
notes_C3: As of April 27th, the CDC "continues to recommend avoiding large events and gatherings. Currently, CDC does not provide numbers to define small and large events."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427181323/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/large-events/considerations-for-events-gatherings.html
notes_C4: no policy change.  Alabama remains under "Safer Apart Order" .    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409144658/https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/legal/assets/order-adph-cov-safer-apart-040721.pdf
notes_C5: no policy change.
notes_C6: no policy change.  Alabama remains under "Safer Apart Order" . Recommendations for staying at home are only applied to those who are feeling sick.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210409144658/https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/legal/assets/order-adph-cov-safer-apart-040721.pdf
notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: no policy change.
notes_E2: On 29 March 2021, the CDC announced a 90 day extension of the federal eviction moratorium. The moratorium is effective 01 April 2021 through 30 June 2021.    The Biden Administration's American Rescue Plan does not provide any other form of explicit contract relief, so the code remains 1.    Link to CDC Eviction Moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145921/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf    Link to White House Press Release on continued renter and landlord support:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329145608/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/03/29/fact-sheet-the-biden-harris-administrations-multi-agency-effort-to-support-renters-and-landlords/
notes_H1: no policy change.
notes_H2: no policy change. If you have symptoms of COVID-19, you should get tested with a nasal test. If you have been exposed to COVID-19 but do not have symptoms you should wait at least 3-4 days after exposure before getting tested. The Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH) recommendation for testing is a PCR (nasal swab) test only.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210415211005/https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/covid19/patients.html
notes_H3: no policy change.
notes_H6: As of April 27th, the mask mandate for federal buildings and recommendations for mask-wearing on public transportation still stand.     The CDC updated its mask-wearing guidance on April 27th for those who have been fully vaccinated, stating:   "You can gather indoors with fully vaccinated people without wearing a mask or staying 6 feet apart."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427062253/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html  See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427035558/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/using-transportation.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426161816/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-protecting-the-federal-workforce-and-requiring-mask-wearing/
notes_H7: changing code from 4 to 5. " Beginning April 5, all individuals age 16 and older are eligible to receive the COVID-19 vaccine in Alabama.  The Pfizer vaccine is the only COVID-19 vaccine currently approved for age 16 and older. Currently, our county health departments are giving the Moderna vaccine. Other providers, such as hospitals and some pharmacies, are giving the Pfizer vaccine. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419210551/https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/covid19vaccine/

name: Arizona
notes_C1: As of May 2, there have been no changes to policy. All schools are required to offer in person options with differing mitigation requirements depending on spread level. The statewide school mask requirement has been dropped.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210310052526/https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-04.pdf    Source: https://archive.vn/VhmjV
notes_C2: As of May 2, there are no changes in this indicator. Previous note reproduced below:    "On March 25th, the governor of Arizona released an executive order that rescinded all county and city orders that enforced mask mandates, with the exception of mask mandates applied to government buildings and public transportation. Previous restrictions on businesses, such as gyms and indoor theatres, have been replaced by recommendations/suggestions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418163253/https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-06.pdf"
notes_C3: As of May 2, there are no changes to this indicator. Previous note reproduced below, with updated source:    "On March 25th, the governor of Arizona released an executive order that events larger than 50 people no longer require local government approval. The city of Phoenix, however, requires applications for gatherings exceeding 50 people to be filed and approved before events can occur. All events require the use of masks and social distancing.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503042131/https://www.phoenix.gov/citymanager/specialevent"
notes_C4: Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Edit:    Code changed to 0 (from 3T), because gathering restrictions apply to public events, not private events. This has been the case since 06 April 2021, possibly earlier (see archived link).    According to the City of Phoenix website, “in response to the pandemic, organized public events at or on City of Phoenix properties of more than 50 people are prohibited unless the city of Phoenix has determined that adequate safety precautions….”     However, “private events, events not open to the public or not hosted at or on City of Phoenix properties which are instead hosted on private property do not require the city's approval no matter how large they are unless a liquor license is required or some other city permit."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406174020/https://www.phoenix.gov/citymanager/specialevent
notes_C5: As of May 2, there are no changes to this indicator.
notes_C6: As of May 2, there are no changes to this indicator.
notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: No policy change. Under the CAA, benefits are reduced and provided through unemployment assistance.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210127043148/https://des.az.gov/services/employment/unemployment-individual
notes_E2: As of April 27th, the eviction moratorium is still in place.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210424154911/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf
notes_H1: As of May 2, there are no changes to this indicator. Public information campaign continues.
notes_H2: As of May 2, there are no changes to this indicator. Testing is generally available.

Previous note reproduced below:    "The State of Arizona is running a comprehensive contact tracing system that involves contacting people who tested positive for COVID-19 via phone call, monitoring symptoms with a text/email system, and contacting all of the people that the case has made close contact with while infectious.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426152951/https://www.azdhs.gov/covid19/index.php"
notes_H6: As of May 2, there are no changes to this indicator. Previous note reproduced below, with updated links:    "Cities like Phoenix and Tucson continue to exert their rights to maintain city-wide mask mandates in place, defying the governor’s executive order on March 25th which rescinded all county and city orders that enforced mask mandates, with the exception of mask mandates applied to government buildings and public transportation.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210405194611/https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2021-06.pdf     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503043643/https://www.phoenix.gov/newsroom/em-and-hs/1353"
notes_H7: As of April 5th, all Arizona counties have made the vaccine available to all people ages 16+. Pfizer, Moderna, and Janssen vaccines are being distributed across the state.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210420172331/https://www.azdhs.gov/covid19/documents/vaccine-phases.pdf

name: California
notes_C1: As of April 25th, with regards to universities, the University of California system will remain on an all remote schedule until the Fall semester.    Los Angeles Unified School District, the largest in the state, is operating with in person, remote, and hybrid options. All elementary schools and early education centers are open and operating, an all middle and high schools are planned to reopen for in-person classes on April 26th. (Source: https://web.archive.org/web/https://achieve.lausd.net/Page/17580)    San Diego Unified School district, the second largest in the state, reopened all classrooms for in person instruction on April 12th, and is planning to hold the 2021-2022 entirely in person. (Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425172439/https://sandiegounified.org/covid-19_status)    The Fresno Unified School District, third largest in the state, has been operating on a hybrid schedule for all grades since April 13th. (Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425172607/https://www.fresnounified.org/covid19/#3-post7010-content)
notes_C2: As of April 25,  there are:  0 counties in the Widespread tier, where many non-essential indoor businesses are closed (including: indoor movie theaters, gyms and fitness centers, bars, amusement parks, offices).  17 counties are in the Substantial tier, some non-essential indoor businesses are closed (including bars),   38 counties are in the Moderate tier,   and 3 in the Minimal tier.    Map of counties and tier assignments: https://archive.ph/MS9sy    Blueprint with Tier info: https://archive.ph/sQrPz
notes_C3: As of April 25th, there are no longer any counties at the "widespread" designation. Most public events are allowed with strict limits on attendance and covid prevention protocols. Some activities require participants to either have tested negative or to provide proof of full vaccination.     Source: https://archive.ph/sQrPz (blueprint info for tiers)    Source: https://archive.ph/MS9sy (listing of counties at each tier)
notes_C4: As of April 25th, there are no longer any counties at the "widespread" designation. At the "substantial" level, at which 17 counties remain, indoor visits are strongly discouraged, but are allowed with a 10 person limit.     Source: https://archive.ph/MS9sy (listing of counties by tier)    Source: https://archive.ph/sQrPz (blueprint info for each tier)
notes_C5: The governor of California designated as essential: "Mass Transit and Passenger Rail includes terminals, operational systems, and supporting infrastructure for passenger services by transit buses, trolleybuses, monorail, heavy rail—also known as subways or metros—light rail, passenger rail, and vanpool/rideshare"     This designation remains in place and was last updated March 25.      Essential workers list: https://archive.fo/Hv8hF
notes_C6: As of April 22, in concordance with the county's move from widespread to substantial tier, Los Angeles has repealed their order requiring residents to remain at home. The new order can be read at the following link: https://archive.vn/TWeRo
notes_C7: As of April 25th, there are no changes to policy regarding internal movement. The previous note is reproduced below, with an updated source link:    "Gov. Newsom has lifted the earlier guidance that residents limit travel to 120 miles from their place of residence. The new guidance reads: "All travelers should follow the CDPH Travel Advisory. It asks that you:        Postpone non-essential travel until you are fully vaccinated      Follow CDC travel guidance      Isolate and follow public health recommendations if you test positive or develop symptoms of COVID-19.    If you are unvaccinated:        Avoid non-essential travel      If you must travel, get tested 1-3 days before travel, and 3-5 days after travel      After travel, self-quarantine for 7 days, no matter what your test results were. If you didn’t get tested, self-quarantine for 10 days."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210423140551/https://covid19.ca.gov/travel/
notes_C8: As of April 27th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426160314/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426010332/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: "Governor Gavin Newsom today announced that he has signed legislation to create a statewide policy for the rehiring of workers laid-off by the pandemic, bolstering the state’s efforts to ensure an equitable recovery from the pandemic.    SB 93 requires employers in the hospitality and business services industries, including hotels, airports and large event centers, to offer new positions to qualified former employees laid off due to COVID-19 within five business days, through 2024.    “As we progress toward fully reopening our economy, it is important we maintain our focus on equity,” said Governor Newsom. “SB 93 keeps us moving in the right direction by assuring hospitality and other workers displaced by the pandemic are prioritized to return to their workplace.”    The bill is the result of continued conversations with the Legislature to advance the goals of last year’s AB 3216."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210416232202/https://www.gov.ca.gov/2021/04/16/governor-newsom-signs-legislation-supporting-workers-displaced-by-the-covid-19-pandemic/
notes_E2: Utilities continue to not be disconnected due to non-payment. The California Public Utilities Commission extended utility customer protection measures directing energy, water, and communications companies under CPUC jurisdiction to suspend customer disconnections for non-payments from April 16, 2021 to June 30, 2021.    The EO extending the statewide moratorium on evictions continues to be in place, lasting through June 30, 2021.     PUC: https://web.archive.org/web/20210316001410/https://docs.cpuc.ca.gov/PublishedDocs/Published/G000/M365/K316/365316626.PDF    EO on rent moratorium: https://web.archive.org/web/20210323154518/https://www.gov.ca.gov/2021/01/29/governor-newsom-signs-legislation-to-extend-eviction-moratorium-and-assist-tenants-and-small-property-owners-impacted-by-covid-19/
notes_H1: As of April 25th, there are no changes to this indicator. CA is still operating a robust COVID information presence online.
notes_H2: As of April 25th, there are no changes to this indicator. Testing is widely available in CA.
notes_H3: As of April 25th, there are no changes to this indicator. The previous note is reproduced below:     "Contact tracing is being conducted in California, but it is unclear how extensive or thorough these measures are.     https://archive.fo/gRyMR"
notes_H6: As of April 25th, there are no changes in masking policy. Previous note reproduced below with updated link:    "Every Californian must wear a mask or face covering in all public and workplace settings where there is a high risk of exposure. This is more important than ever with new, more easily transmitted variants of COVID-19 on the rise."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425233741/https://covid19.ca.gov/masks-and-ppe/
notes_H7: Recoded to reflect previous change to 5G    "On April 24th, Governor Newsom announced that California would resume administration of the J&J vaccine following the CDC's recommendation to resume its usage. Pfizer, Moderna, and, now, J&J vaccines are being administered in California.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/california-to-resume-jj-vaccines-after-pause-lifted/2527471/"

name: Colorado
notes_C1: April 28, Colorado State University and University of Colorado will require upcoming its students to be vaccinated before attending fall semester, joining three other higher education institutions (Fort Lewis College, University of Denver, and Colorado Spring College) These measures are in full support of Gov. Polis.    Source:  https://www.9news.com/article/news/health/coronavirus/vaccine/colorado-colleges-covid-vaccine-requirements/73-319233b5-e776-41a3-8352-480ef5eb629b
notes_C2: Counties with strictest regulations are in Level Orange: offices are strongly recommended to work remotely, restaurants at 25% capacity or max 50 people, retail at 50% capacity.    Summary: https://archive.vn/TIiUt  Public health order: https://archive.vn/6PHbv
notes_C3: Per the Department of Public Health and Environment of Colorado, events are recommended to be canceled unless appropriate social distancing measures can be taken.    Summary: https://archive.vn/TIiUt  Public health order: https://archive.vn/6PHbv
notes_C4: Counties with strictest regulations are in Level Orange: gatherings restricted to up to 10 people.    Summary: https://archive.vn/TIiUt  Public health order: https://archive.vn/6PHbv
notes_C5: RTD's COVID-19 service plan continues - mask-wearing requirements, limited capacity on buses, services/lines running reduced.     Link: https://archive.fo/84v6F
notes_C6: Counties with strictest regulations are in Level Orange: people advised to stay at home as much as possible.    Summary: https://archive.vn/TIiUt  Public health order: https://archive.vn/6PHbv
notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: The Governor extended an Executive Order ordering expedited unemployment insurance claim processing to provide relief to Coloradans impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.   Link: https://archive.fo/IHZ7V
notes_E2: Governor Polis signed an Executive Order related to the protection of tenants from eviction during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic in Colorado.  Under the Executive Order, tenants now have a 30-day period to cure any default for nonpayment of rent. Previously, tenants only had a ten-day cure period.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422203641/https://www.colorado.gov/governor/news/4886-governor-polis-takes-action-response-covid-19-pandemic
notes_H1: Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) launched the "Power the Comeback" information campaign to bolster access to credible COVID-19 vaccine information.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210416140354/https://covid19.colorado.gov/press-release/state-asks-coloradans-to-power-the-comeback
notes_H2: CDPHE expands at-home COVID-19 testing program (Binax At-home Rapid Testing Kit) to all public-facing employees free of charge. Public-facing employees include, but is not limited to retail workers, hotel and other hospitality employees, delivery and truck drivers, etc.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210413161727/https://covid19.colorado.gov/press-release/cdphe-expands-at-home-covid-19-testing-program-to-all-public-facing-employees
notes_H3: Couldn't find more recent news, but sources in mid-late November indicate that contact tracing capacity wasn't keeping up with the number of surging cases at the time.  Links: https://archive.fo/00vsj ; https://archive.fo/wH1g5    More recent (Jan 10) anecdote/Twitter thread suggesting limited contact tracing: https://archive.fo/dkEVT
notes_H6: Gov. Jared Polis (D-Colorado) announced Sunday that he had extended Colorado's mask order, but added an amendment that makes maskless indoor gatherings possible. This order allows people to take off their masks in indoor spaces where more than 10 people are gathered, as long as at least 80% of them have shown proof of vaccination.    A spokesperson for the governor said that proof could be in the form of a vaccination card, a picture of the card on a cell phone, or a copy of a person's immunization records.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504032949/https://www.9news.com/article/news/health/coronavirus/vaccine/polis-extends-mask-order-indoor-gatherings/73-7606149e-2462-430c-a2fc-954cc2a26628
notes_H7: Recoded to 5G    "In response to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) announcement that providers should resume using the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) and the Colorado Joint Vaccine Task Force are alerting providers they can proceed with using the Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) COVID-19 vaccine immediately.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426173433/https://covid19.colorado.gov/press-release/colorado-resumes-use-of-johnson-johnson-vaccine-to-help-end-the-pandemic"

notes_C5: No change
notes_C6: Update: "As of April 2, 2021, CDC has updated their travel guidance; since fully vaccinated travelers are less likely to contract and spread COVID-19, they can travel safely within the United States.    Fully vaccinated persons, meaning persons who are at least 14 days or more after the last dose of their vaccine series, can travel within the United States and do not have to test before or after travel (unless their destination requires it) and do not have to quarantine after travel.    Fully vaccinated persons should still:    Wear a mask over their nose and mouth  Stay 6 feet from others and avoid crowds  Wash hands often or use hand sanitizer"    For unvaccinated:   Before Travel:   Plan ahead and check if your airline or destination requires testing, health information, or other documentation.  Some destinations require a viral test 1-3 days prior to travel. Visit the Connecticut Testing Locator or call 211 to locate a testing site.  Keep a copy of your test results with you during travel in case you are asked for them.  Anyone who develops signs/symptoms of COVID-19 prior to travel should stay home and get tested.    After Travel:  Review CDC guidance for post-travel quarantine and testing  Get tested 3-5 days after travel AND self-quarantine at home for a full 7 days after travel.  Continue to stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel, even if your test is negative.  If your test is positive, isolate yourself to protect others from getting infected.  If you do not get tested, stay home and self-quarantine for a full 10 days after travel.  Remember to self-monitor for signs and symptoms of COVID-19 while in quarantine. If at any time during your quarantine you develop signs and symptoms of COVID-19, self-isolate (including away from other members of your travel party), contact a healthcare provider, and seek testing.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422211730/https://portal.ct.gov/coronavirus/travel

This includes fully vaccinated people. notes_E1: Public health emergency extended until at least May 20  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422213207/https://ctmirror.org/2021/04/19/eviction-moratorium-extended-until-public-health-emergency-order-ends/    From the executive order 9P:  "NOW, THEREFORE, I, NED LAMONT, Governor of the State of Connecticut, by virtue of the  authority vested in me by the Constitution and the laws of the State of Connecticut, and pursuant  to the public health and civil preparedness emergencies declared on March 10, 2020 and renewed on September 1, 2020 and the new public health and civil preparedness emergencies declared on September 1, 2020, do hereby ORDER AND DIRECT:    1. Increase in Weekly Benefit Amount and Qualification for Lost Wages Assistance. Notwithstanding any provision of Chapter 567 of the Connecticut General Statutes to the contrary, during the weeks beginning July 26, 2020, and ending on September 5, 2020, individuals who were eligible for a Weekly Benefit Amount of less than $100.00 and had not exhausted their state regular unemployment benefits by July 26, 2020, shall have their Weekly Benefit Amount raised to $100.00, and such individuals shall be permitted to apply for Lost Wages Assistance as a result. With respect to employers who make payments in lieu of contributions pursuant to Section 31-225 of the Connecticut General Statutes (reimbursing employers), for individuals who are affected by this Executive Order No. 9P, the amount otherwise due from the employer in lieu of contributions shall be reduced by an amount equal to the difference between the individual’s Weekly Benefit Amount to be paid pursuant to this Order and the Weekly Benefit Amount which was or would have been calculated pursuant to Chapter 567 prior to this Order. The Commissioner of Labor may issue any implementing orders that he deems necessary to effectuate this order.    This order shall take effect immediately and remain in effect for the duration of the existing  renewed and newly declared civil preparedness and public health emergencies, unless earlier  modified or terminated by me."    From executive order 10:  "Exclusion of individual stimulus payments from benefit eligibility calculations: Repeats and expands the provisions of Executive Order No. 7CC, which exempted any CARES Act stimulus payments from eligibility calculations for state-provided benefits. This expands the exemption to all federal COVID-related stimulus to capture CARES Act II stimulus."    Sources:  https://archive.vn/gkjem    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307192050/https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9P.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307192106/https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-10.pdf
notes_E2: "Gov. Ned Lamont plans to extend the state’s eviction moratorium until the public health emergency expires on May 20."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422213207/https://ctmirror.org/2021/04/19/eviction-moratorium-extended-until-public-health-emergency-order-ends/    "Governor Ned Lamont, members of Connecticut’s Congressional delegation, and Connecticut Housing Commissioner Seila Mosquera-Bruno today announced the launch of UniteCT, a new state program to provide rental and utility assistance to qualified Connecticut households financially impacted by COVID-19.    As further detailed in the program guidelines, UniteCT may provide up to $10,000 in rental assistance and up to $1,500 in electric utility arrearage payments to landlords and utility companies on behalf of approved tenants. Tenants and landlords will be able to complete and track applications online from any computer or smart phone. Assistance will be available through a call center and at housing counseling agencies and other community partners across the state."    Source:  https://archive.vn/WbftJ
notes_H1: Notes  No change. Campaigns appear up to date.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210319095243/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base

notes_H3: No change.    "Contact tracing is the process of contacting all people who have tested positive for COVID-19 or have had contact with someone who tested positive. It is possible to be infected with COVID-19 and have no symptoms, so contact tracing is currently one of the best ways to identify and notify people who may be infected in order to slow the spread of COVID-19. Participating in contact tracing is a way to protect you, your family, and your community.    Contact tracers from the local and state health department will be in touch with you if you test positive for COVID-19, and will also call people you were in close contact with – but will keep your information protected. You will see “CT COVID TRACE” or the number for your local health department on your caller ID."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322043051/https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/ContaCT
notes_H6: "Gov. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: Extensive protections remain. This policy remains coded at 2.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316220040/https://coronavirus.dc.gov/utilityhelp
notes_H1: As of April 12, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_H2: As of April 12, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_H3: As of April 12, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_H6: As of April 12, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_H7: As of April 12, 2021, all Washington DC residents age 16 and older are eligible to receive the COVID-19 vaccine. Vaccines offered include Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson&Johnson. This policy has thus been upgraded from 3G to 5G, as eligibility is now universal for 16+.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412205310/https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/release_content/attachments/Situational-Update-Presentation_04-12-21.pdf

name: Delaware
notes_C1: As of May 3, the majority of schools in Delaware are operating remote learning, in-person learning or a hybrid learning model.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503161008if_/https://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/2021/04/27/state-plan-students-catch-up-summer-school-more-online-tools/4861759001/
notes_C2: As of May 2, the Twenty-Seventh Modification: State of Emergency Declaration, issued by Gov. Carney remains in effect. The order is allowing some sectors to reopen under the phase 2 reopening plan (food and drinks establishments, retail premises and museums, for example) with restrictions regarding social distancing, hygiene and reduced capacity limits. Some sectors such as indoor children's play areas, arcades and water parks are not allowed to reopen unless they submit facility-specific plans to the state for consideration.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426204907/https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/twenty-seventh-modification-state-of-emergency-declaration/
notes_C3: As of May 1, the Twenty-Seventh Modification: State of Emergency Declaration, issued by Gov. Carney remains in effect. Regarding, public events while some outdoor gatherings can take place this order states "notwithstanding the occupancy determinations in this paragraph, any fire occupancy requirements that would permit more than one hundred and fifty (150) people at any one time must first submit a plan to DPH. Plans may not be implemented until approved by DPH." While some public events with limited capacity can go ahead, they must follow strict guidelines and anything larger has to be approved by the DPH.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426204907/https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/twenty-seventh-modification-state-of-emergency-declaration/
notes_C4: As of April 26, the Twenty-Seventh Modification: State of Emergency Declaration, issued by Gov. Carney remains in effect. This order was last modified on 1 April 2021. Regarding indoor gatherings, this order states "Indoor gatherings or events at any business or indoor space open to the public of up to the lesser of fifty percent (50%) stated fire occupancy or twenty-five (25) people (e.g. weddings and receptions, graduations, birthday parties, funeral receptions, etc.) and private indoor gatherings or events of up to ten (10) persons (e.g. dinner parties, house parties, birthday parties) are permitted in Phase 2" if a number of social distancing and hygiene requirements are met. Regarding outdoor events this order states "Any business or space without a stated fire occupancy requirement may host outdoor social, community, recreational, and leisure events of no more than one hundred and fifty (150) people, including but not limited to weddings, funerals, concerts, parades, festivals, conventions, fundraisers, sporting events and fairs".     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426204907/https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/twenty-seventh-modification-state-of-emergency-declaration/    Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Edit:    Code changed to 4G (from 2G) to reflect the more stringent indoor gathering requirement, despite less stringent outdoor gathering restrictions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211328/https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2021/02/Seventh-Revision-to-the-27th-Modification-of-the-Declaration-of-a-SOE-State-of-Delaware-02192021.pdf
notes_C5: As of 19th April 2021, there is no evidence of public transport closures in Delaware. The DART's strategy outline indicates that most services are running as normal.     Source: https://archive.vn/iWuEb
notes_C6: The official advice of the Delaware government is to "stay home if you are sick", but as of 19th April 2021 there are no further stay at home requirements, so this indicator remains at 0.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419125921/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/
notes_C7: As of May 1, the Twenty-Seventh Modification: State of Emergency Declaration, issued by Gov. Carney remains in effect. This order maintains that individuals who travel out of state for sporting competitions are "strongly encouraged to immediately self-quarantine in accordance with DPH guidance from the time of entry into Delaware or for the duration of the individual’s presence in Delaware, whichever period is shorter".     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426204907/https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/twenty-seventh-modification-state-of-emergency-declaration/
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: The additional temporary food benefits given to Delaware households affected by the lack of free school meals last up to July 2021. As these benefits are temporary and specifically related to the pandemic, and as they amount to only $6.82 per eligible child per day, this indicator remains at 1F.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210329212729/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/03/29/delaware-households-affected-by-school-closings-during-pandemic-will-receive-additional-temporary-food-benefits/
notes_E2: As of 19th April 2021, Delaware's Covid-19 Rental Assistance programme is still in effect. Therefore this indicator remains at 2.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210412152329/https://decovidhousinghelp.com/
notes_H1: As of May 1, Delaware is still operating a coordinated public health campaign.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426210712/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/community-resources/
notes_H2: As of May 3, the state is still offering testing to anyone with or without symptoms. Testing methods available include at home testing, community sites or antigen testing/rapid tests.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426211041/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/testing/
notes_H3: As of May 3, the Delaware Contact Tracing Program is still operational and comprehensive.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426211204/https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/contact-tracing/
notes_H6: As of May 3, the Twenty-Seventh Modification: State of Emergency Declaration, issued by Gov. Carney remains in effect. This order was last modified on 1 April 2021. This order states that face coverings must be worn in public. There are very few circumstances where face coverings are not mandatory as the order states they are "not required in an outdoor space open to the public when an individual can maintain at least six (6) feet of social distance between members of separate households, unless otherwise specified" or in certain circumstances like eating or drinking.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426204907/https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/twenty-seventh-modification-state-of-emergency-declaration/
notes_H7: On 6th April 2021, Delaware opened its vaccination programme to everybody over the age of 16. As this indicates universal 16+ eligibility, moved to 5G. However, note that availability of vaccine is limited and individuals are warned that they may need to wait a number of weeks before a vaccine becomes available.     As of Monday, April 5, Delaware had administered 502,927 doses of the COVID-19 vaccine. Nearly 35 percent of Delaware’s population had received at least one shot.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210406145309/https://news.delaware.gov/2021/04/06/covid-19-vaccination-program-open-to-delawareans-16/

name: Florida
notes_C1: No new updates. See note on 11 April 2021 for more details.    As of 12 April 2021, University of Miami lifted its campus curfew to align with the lifting of the Miami-Dade County midnight curfew.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426024039/https://messages.miami.edu/messages/2021/04/04-12-21-covid-curfew-lifted.html
notes_C2: Florida Executive Order 21-45 is still in effect (until 26 April 2021), and does not impose any workplace closings.    As of 13 April 2021, the City of Miami Beach is allowing sidewalk cafes to operate once more, but encourages establishments to accept guests by reservation only.    No new updates: Miami-Dade County allows restaurants and other food establishments to operate up to 100% capacity provided they maintain social distancing of 6 feet and face coverings on people who are not eating or drinking.    No new updates: Broward County food service establishments are allowed to operate with up to 100% of maximum indoor occupancy provided the establishment abides by certain social distancing and facial covering restrictions (Chapter 12).     Link to EO 21-45: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406142146/https://flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-45.pdf  Link to City of Miami Beach State of Emergency Order (15 April to 21 April 2021):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425194622/https://www.miamibeachfl.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Declaration-of-a-State-of-Emergency-Extended-Through-April-21-2021-1.pdf  Link to City of Miami Beach emergency measures (effective 22 April to 28 April 2021):   https://web.archive.org/web/20210425195013/https://www.miamibeachfl.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Phase-3-Opening-Order-and-Emergency-Measures-Effective-April-22-2021.pdf  Link to Miami Dade County Emergency Order 33-20 (still in effect):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425211449/https://www.miamidade.gov/global/initiatives/coronavirus/emergency-orders/emergency-order-33-20.page  Link to Broward County Comprehensive Emergency Order (effective 19 April 2021):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425204350/https://www.broward.org/CoronaVirus/Documents/Comprehensive-Emergency-Order-21-02.pdf
notes_C3: Florida Executive Order 21-45 is still in effect (until 26 April 2021), and does not impose any public event restrictions.    Miami-Dade County still prohibits 10 or more individuals in public, but does not limit the number of people at a religious service.    Broward County still restricts public event venues such as movie theaters, auditoriums, playhouses, concert halls, museums to 50% maximum occupancy (Chapter 15).    Link to EO 21-45: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406142146/https://flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-45.pdf  Link to Miami Dade Emergency Order 33-20 (still in effect):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425211449/https://www.miamidade.gov/global/initiatives/coronavirus/emergency-orders/emergency-order-33-20.page  Link to Broward County Comprehensive Emergency Order (effective 19 April 2021):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425204350/https://www.broward.org/CoronaVirus/Documents/Comprehensive-Emergency-Order-21-02.pdf
notes_C4: Florida Executive Order 21-45 is still in effect (until 26 April 2021), and there are no statewide restrictions on gatherings. Broward County still prohibits private gatherings of more than 10 people, with some exceptions.     Link to EO 21-45: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406142146/https://flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-45.pdf  Link to Broward County Comprehensive Emergency Order (effective 19 April 2021):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425204350/https://www.broward.org/CoronaVirus/Documents/Comprehensive-Emergency-Order-21-02.pdf
notes_C5: No new updates. Executive Order 21-45 is still in effect (until 26 April 2021), and does not impose any public transport restrictions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406142146/https://flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-45.pdf
notes_C6: As of 13 April 2021, Miami-Dade County no longer imposes a county-wide curfew. The City of Miami Beach also does not impose any curfews. No evidence of curfew found for the City of Fort Lauderdale, Broward County, or Palm Beach County. None of the emergency orders recommend staying at home. Code changed to 0 to reflect lack of shelter in place measures.    Article on Miami-Dade County lifting curfew (17 April 2021): https://web.archive.org/web/20210425203442/https://www.nbcmiami.com/news/local/businesses-nightclubs-breathing-sigh-of-relief-after-miami-dade-county-weekend-curfew-lifted/2431165/  Link to City of Miami Beach emergency measures (effective 22 April to 28 April 2021):   https://web.archive.org/web/20210425195013/https://www.miamibeachfl.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Phase-3-Opening-Order-and-Emergency-Measures-Effective-April-22-2021.pdf  Link to Broward County Comprehensive Emergency Order (effective 19 April 2021): https://web.archive.org/web/20210425204350/https://www.broward.org/CoronaVirus/Documents/Comprehensive-Emergency-Order-21-02.pdf  Link to Palm Beach County Emergency Order No 28 (effective since 29 September 2020):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210422163103/https://discover.pbcgov.org/PDF/COVID19/PBC-EO-28.pdf  Article mentioning Fort Lauderdale not imposing curfew:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425204034/https://www.palmbeachpost.com/story/news/2021/04/15/desantis-orders-worsened-spring-break-coronavirus-surge-mayors-say/7140623002/
notes_C7: Florida Executive Order 21-45 is still in effect (until 26 April 2021). There are no statewide restrictions on movement between cities and regions within Florida.     From 22 April 2021 to 28 April 2021, the City of Miami Beach amended its emergency measures to reinstate restrictions on vehicular traffic on Ocean Drive. Code changed back to 2T.    Link to statewide EO 21-45: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406142146/https://flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-45.pdf  Link to City of Miami Beach emergency measures (effective 22 April to 28 April 2021):   https://web.archive.org/web/20210425195013/https://www.miamibeachfl.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Phase-3-Opening-Order-and-Emergency-Measures-Effective-April-22-2021.pdf
notes_C8: As of April 27th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426160314/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426010332/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: As of April 27th, the eviction moratorium is still in place.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210424154911/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf
notes_H1: No new updates. The Florida Department of Health is disseminating information about COVID-19 vaccines via its website and twitter. Miami-Dade County continues its social media campaign to slow the spread of COVID-19 and encourages mask-wearing and social distancing.     Code remains 2T because of heterogeneity in public health messaging in Florida.    Link to FL Department of Health twitter: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425173209/https://twitter.com/HealthyFla  Link to FL Department of Health website: http://web.archive.org/web/20210425173047/https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/  Link to Miami-Dade County COVID-19 website: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425172812/https://www.miamidade.gov/global/initiatives/coronavirus/home.page
notes_H2: Nearly all testing sites within Miami-Dade and Broward County are testing asymptomatic people. Many testing sites in Palm Beach County are testing asymptomatic people.     Code changed to 3 to reflect the large number of testing sites available for asymptomatic people in the three most populous counties in Florida.     Miami-Dade: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425173930if_/https://www.miamidade.gov/global/initiatives/coronavirus/testing-locations.page  Broward: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425175103/https://www.broward.org/CoronaVirus/Pages/Collection-Sites.aspx  Palm Beach: https://archive.vn/bjzAu
notes_H3: No new updates after checking relevant sources. See note on 12 April 2021 for more details.    Link to FL Department of Health FAQ page with contact tracing information: https://web.archive.org/web/20210425175823/https://floridahealthcovid19.gov/frequently-asked-questions/
notes_H6: Executive Order 21-45 is still in effect (until 26 April 2021), and does not impose a statewide mask mandate.     Miami-Dade County continues to enforce a strict mask mandate. On 12 April 2021, it released a "A New Normal Handbook" that outlines the details of the mask mandate. These details are still in accordance with Miami-Dade Emergency Order 33-20.     Link to Executive Order 21-45:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210406142146/https://flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2021/EO_21-45.pdf  Link to the Miami-Dade New Normal Handbook:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210414123045/https://www.miamidade.gov/information/library/safety-guidelines.pdf  Link to the Miami-Dade Emergency Order 33-20:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425181620/https://www.miamidade.gov/global/initiatives/coronavirus/emergency-orders/emergency-order-33-20.page
notes_H7: On 25 April 2021, Florida resumed administering Johnson & Johnson vaccines (approved for 18+ years of age) at its four FEMA sites, in line with updated guidance from the CDC and the FDA (which recommended lifting the pause on the J&J vaccine on 23 April 2021).      https://web.archive.org/web/20210425183309/https://www.mynews13.com/fl/orlando/news/2021/04/25/florida-to-resume-use-of-johnson-and-johnson-vaccine-at-fema-sites

name: Georgia
notes_C1: No new updates. Statewide Executive Order 03.31.21.03  remains effective until 30 April 2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502233300/https://gov.georgia.gov/press-releases/2021-04-07/georgia-open-business
notes_C2: No new updates. Statewide Executive Order 03.31.21.03  remains effective until 30 April 2021, which allows all work places to open with Covid-19 preventative measures.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502233300/https://gov.georgia.gov/press-releases/2021-04-07/georgia-open-business
notes_C3: No new updates. Statewide Executive Order 03.31.21.03  remains effective until 30 April 2021, which allows large events with Covid-19 preventative measures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502233300/https://gov.georgia.gov/press-releases/2021-04-07/georgia-open-business
notes_C4: No new updates. Statewide Executive Order 03.31.21.03  remains effective until 30 April 2021, which eliminates bans on gatherings.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502233300/https://gov.georgia.gov/press-releases/2021-04-07/georgia-open-business
notes_C5: No new updates. Statewide Executive Order 03.31.21.03  remains effective until 30 April 2021, which does not provide limits for public transport.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502233300/https://gov.georgia.gov/press-releases/2021-04-07/georgia-open-business
notes_C6: No new updates. Statewide Executive Order 03.31.21.03  remains effective until 30 April 2021, which eliminates shelter-in-place.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502233300/https://gov.georgia.gov/press-releases/2021-04-07/georgia-open-business
notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: As of April 27th, the eviction moratorium is still in place.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210424154911/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf
notes_H1: The Georgia Department of Health website continues to provide information on Covid-19 guidance, testing, and vaccines.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502235009/https://dph.georgia.gov/covidtesting
notes_H2: No new updates. Testing continues to be available "to all Georgians who request it, whether they have symptoms or not."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502235009/https://dph.georgia.gov/covidtesting
notes_H3: No new updates. GA continues to contract trace but not enough evidence to conclude that it is comprehensive.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502235412/https://dph.georgia.gov/contact-tracing
notes_H6: Chatham county extends mask mandate until May 30, 2021.    "Masks must be worn over the nose and mouth in public spaces, including commercial establishments, government buildings and any time people gather in groups of 10 or more."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210502235919/https://www.wsav.com/news/coronavirus/city-of-beaufort-chatham-county-mask-mandates-expire-at-midnight/
notes_H7: Pfizer vaccine available to those 16 years and older. On April 23, 2021 The Department of Public Health announced it will resume Johnson and Johnson vaccine administration.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210501145504/https://dph.georgia.gov/covid-vaccine

name: Hawaii
notes_C1: According to the Hawaii Department of Education press release on March 11, "The Hawaii State Department of Education (HIDOE) recently announced a goal to increase in-person instruction at elementary schools during the fourth quarter (March 22-May 28). The overall aim is to safely maximize in-person learning opportunities for elementary students for the remainder of the 2020-21 school year. Because campuses are in various stages of reopening, timing will vary by school."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210504190333/https://www.hawaiipublicschools.org/ConnectWithUs/MediaRoom/PressReleases/Pages/Fourth-Quarter-Reopening-Ramp-Up.aspx
notes_C2: The March 24, 2021 Emergency Order 2021-04, issued by the Mayor of the city and county of Honolulu is still in effect. The City and County of Honolulu are currently in Tier 3 (out of 4) during a "pause and evaluation" period until at least May 5. Essential business is allowed, but "All businesses with a facility in the City, except Essential Businesses, and Designated Businesses and Operations, are required to cease all activities within such facilities, except Minimum Basic Operations. For clarity, businesses may also continue operations consisting exclusively of employees or contractors performing activities at their own residences (i.e., working from home)." The Order is in effect through May 10, 2021.         https://web.archive.org/web/20210428230834/http://www.honolulu.gov/rep/site/may/may_docs/2103140-CCH_Emergency_Order_No._2021-04_certified_-_signed.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210504191007/https://www.oneoahu.org/reopening-strategy
notes_C3: Social gatherings continue to be limited (as of May 4). In the "Act with Care" level, residents are advised to adhere to guidelines to limit crowds. Dance, social, and night life establishments remain closed in the city and county of Honolulu in Tier 3.  Social gatherings are capped at 10 people. "Static events" are allowed at reduced capacity with assigned seats, weddings capped at 100 people and must be outside. On Maui, exceptions to provisions for special events must be approved by the County of Maui. "Under the supervision of professional event planners or venues, commercial events (such as luau) may be conducted with the following restrictions: a. Outdoor venues only. b. Maximum 100 persons, including staff. c. Table seating required. Maximum of 10 persons per table. Each table should be reserved for members of the same household only (no intermixing of parties).      https://web.archive.org/web/20210505004610/https://www.oneoahu.org/reopening-strategy    https://web.archive.org/web/20210505004756/https://www.mauicounty.gov/DocumentCenter/View/125111/COM_Public-Health-Emergency-Rules
notes_C4: The State of Hawaii Covid-19 Portal continues to state, "Limit gatherings to five people or fewer. Local police are enforcing safe gathering sizes!" In Tier 3, the county and city of Honolulu limit social gatherings to 10 people. In Maui, the public health emergency rules in effect April 9 state, "Indoor or outdoor social gatherings of up to 5 persons are permitted. Face coverings are required and physical distancing of at least 6 feet between separate social gatherings must be maintained."     Kauai is in Tier 4 (of 4), 10 people are allowed to gather indoors, 25 outdoors.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210505005958/https://www.kauai.gov/COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210505005921/https://www.kauai.gov/Portals/0/Civil_Defense/EmergencyProclamations/2010101-COK_Mayor%27s%20Emergency%20Rule%20No_%2019%20%28part%202%29%20-%20signed.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210505004610/https://www.oneoahu.org/reopening-strategy    https://web.archive.org/web/20210505004756/https://www.mauicounty.gov/DocumentCenter/View/125111/COM_Public-Health-Emergency-Rules
notes_C5: Based on searches, there are no measures to close public transportation. Honolulu's bus service encourages riders to limit their bus/van trips to essential travel only.    https://archive.vn/5cVSu
notes_C6: The City and County of Honolulu's Emergency Order 2021-04, which went into effect March 24 and will remain in effect through May 10, 2021.   "All individuals currently living within the City may leave their residences to engage in Essential Activities, maintain Essential Governmental Functions, operate/visit Essential Businesses, or operate/visit/utilize Designated Businesses and Operations. All other activities, businesses, and operations are prohibited."    The County of Maui's emergency rules continue to be in effect, with Rule 1: Act with Care stating, "All individuals currently within the County are  encouraged to stay at their residence or place of lodging, except as provided in these Rules" (for essential activities, etc).     Maui: https://archive.vn/s7cg0  Honolulu: https://archive.vn/QcejT
notes_C7: Governor Ige's 19th Proclamation states that, "all persons traveling from within the State to the counties of Kaua‘i, Hawai‘i, Maui and Kalawao shall be subject to mandatory self-quarantine. The period of self-quarantine shall begin from the day of entry into the county and shall last 10 days or the duration of the person’s presence in the county, whichever is shorter."    Maui's emergency order 2021-04 states that "all persons traveling to the County of Maui, whether interisland or from out of state, shall be subject to health screening."   https://web.archive.org/web/20210505172707/https://coronavirus-response-county-of-hawaii-hawaiicountygis.hub.arcgis.com/datasets/806cc065f2c3459c8a674c48ac81aa49    https://web.archive.org/web/20210505172244/https://www.mauicounty.gov/DocumentCenter/View/125111/COM_Public-Health-Emergency-Rules
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: Income support continues to be in place, including pandemic unemployment benefits. Hawaii's Department of Labor provides additional resources on their website for those who have exhausted their benefits.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210505175055/https://labor.hawaii.gov/blog/main/resources-for-unemployment-insurance-claimants-with-exhausted-benefits/
notes_E2: Gov. David Ige’s 19th emergency proclamation for COVID-19 extends the eviction moratorium, prohibiting evictions of tenants for failure to pay all or a portion of the rent, maintenance fees, utility charges, taxes or other required fees for the rental unit.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426210158/https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/2104031-ATG_Nineteenth-Emergency-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf
notes_H1: The state's website on Covid-19 resources remains active and updated regularly.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210505173548/https://hawaiicovid19.com/
notes_H2: Testing is widely available, including some free testing options, across the state.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210505171635/https://hawaiicovid19.com/testing-isolation-quarantine/
notes_H3: Up-to-date information on contact tracing in Hawaii remains elusive.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210505174047/https://hiema-hub.hawaii.gov/app/2c689a448b3045ccafdf86c40a8bf37e
notes_H6: Governor Ige's Proclamation 19, which extends until June, continues the statewide face covering requirement. All people ages 5 and older are required to wear masks over nose and mouth when in public, with some exceptions.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426210158/https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/2104031-ATG_Nineteenth-Emergency-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210505170116/https://hawaiicovid19.com/mask-guidance/
notes_H7: COVID-19 vaccinations are available for all Hawai‘i residents who are at least 16 years old. Maui county has fully vaccinated 35% of its population (the least vaccinated county), and Kauai has fully vaccinated 50% of its population (the most vaccinated county). Honolulu and Hawaii counties are at 36 and 38% fully vaccinated, respectively (as of May 5).     According to the Department of Health, Moderna and Pfizer vaccines are currently being offered, and clinics may soon resume use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine (as of May 5).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210505165735/https://coronavirus-response-county-of-hawaii-hawaiicountygis.hub.arcgis.com/pages/vaccine-information    https://archive.vn/qS2T8

notes_C1: As of April 23rd, Des Moines Public Schools (DMPS) still adopted hybrid learning method.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210426055307/https://www.dmschools.org/dmps-covid-19-dashboard/
