notes_C3: As of May 2nd, there was no new proclamation issued by Governor Kim Reynolds. Event organizers should follow Covid-19 protocols as stated by April 2nd proclamation.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502101314if_/https://coronavirus.iowa.gov/pages/proclamations
notes_C4: As of May 2nd, there was no new proclamation issued by Governor Kim Reynolds. https://web.archive.org/web/20210502101314if_/https://coronavirus.iowa.gov/pages/proclamations
notes_C5: As of May 2nd, there was no new proclamation issued by Governor Kim Reynolds. https://web.archive.org/web/20210502101314if_/https://coronavirus.iowa.gov/pages/proclamations
notes_C6: As of May 2nd, there was no new proclamation issued by Governor Kim Reynolds. https://web.archive.org/web/20210502101314if_/https://coronavirus.iowa.gov/pages/proclamations
notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of April 6th, individuals who were unemployed were still eligible to receive payment between $203 and $605 per week. Because the benefits were under 50% of the median salary in Iowa in 2020 ($43,000), this policy is coded 1F.    PUA: http://web.archive.org/web/20210320204336/https://www.iowaworkforcedevelopment.gov/pua-information   Median salary: http://web.archive.org/web/20210312055736/https://dqydj.com/average-income-by-state-median-top-percentiles/
notes_E2: As of April 13th, the federal moratorium on evictions was still in place. The moratorium is set to expire on June 30th.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419062920/https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/29/success/cdc-eviction-order-extended/index.html
notes_H1: As of April 6th, the state of Iowa along with the Iowa Department of Health were still active in coordinating Covid-19 public campaign.  Twitter: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405173903/https://twitter.com/IAPublicHealth/status/1379126344664154116   Iowa's Covid-19 website: http://web.archive.org/web/20210411195735/https://coronavirus.iowa.gov/
notes_H2: As of April 19th, there were five testing sites and eleven clinics where Iowans could get tested for Covid-19. The sites and clinics prioritized testing individuals who showed symptoms of Covid-19.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419071044if_/https://www.testiowa.com/en
notes_H3: As of January 4th, there was no evidence that the state of Iowa had ramped up contact tracing. Thus, the coding stays the same.
notes_H6: As of May 2nd, Des Moines, Dubuque, and other cities in Iowa still enforced public mask mandate.  Des Moines: https://web.archive.org/web/20210424052227/https://www.dsm.city/departments/city_manager_s_office/covid-19/face_covering_mandate.php   Dubuque: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502105552/https://www.cityofdubuque.org/2941/Face-Covering-Mandate-What-You-Need-To-K
notes_H7: Despite the acknowledgement of vaccine shortage on Iowa government’s website, there was plenty of vaccine in Iowa this week due to weakening demand. 43 out of 99 counties in Iowa declined vaccine shipment. The shipment was rerouted to other counties in Iowa that needed it. Therefore, the code is changed to 5 - Universal.    News: http://web.archive.org/web/20210424050931/https://www.thegazette.com/health-care-medicine/as-vaccine-demand-slows-in-iowa-public-health-pivots-to-outreach/   News: http://web.archive.org/web/20210424051354/https://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/latest-india-reports-record-number-cases-deaths-77208207  Iowa government’s website: http://web.archive.org/web/20210424051455/https://vaccinate.iowa.gov/eligibility/

name: Idaho
notes_C1: K-12 schools remain open in Idaho, with all but 8 districts reporting in-person learning. The other 8 were hybrid (mix of in-person and online).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503030432/https://ioem.maps.arcgis.com/sharing/oauth2/authorize?client_id=opsdashboard&response_type=token&state=%7B%22portalUrl%22%3A%22https%3A%2F%2Fioem.maps.arcgis.com%22%7D&expiration=20160&redirect_uri=https%3A%2F%2Fioem.maps.arcgis.com%2Fapps%2Fopsdashboard%2Findex.html&redirectToUserOrgUrl=true
notes_C2: On May 2, Idaho is still operating under its "Stage 3 Stay Healthy Guidelines", which allow businesses to open as long as hygiene and distancing is being kept, and the following bar/restaurant guidelines are in place:  "All patrons should remain seated while consuming food or drink or when otherwise remaining on the premises, except for when entering, exiting, or using the restroom; seating should be arranged and maintained so that tables are spaced at least six feet apart; and nightclubs should continue to operate as a bar, subject to the requirements of this Section".     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503025711/https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-3-stay-healthy-guidelines/
notes_C3: As of May 2, Idaho is still operating under its "Stage 3 Stay Healthy Guidelines" which state "Gatherings should be limited to 50 or fewer people and adhere to the Physical Distancing and Sanitation Requirements in Section 3 [of the guidelines]"  Gatherings of over 50 may occur under the following:  "Gatherings exceeding the size and capacity limitations specified in Section 1(a) may receive an exemption if the organizer submits a plan for the gathering to the local health district having authority where the gathering is to occur and signs an attestation agreeing to comply with the provisions of the plan submitted to the local health district. The submitted plan and any exempted gatherings should adhere to the Physical Distancing and Sanitation Requirements in Section 3".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503025711/https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-3-stay-healthy-guidelines/
notes_C4: As of May 2, Idaho is still operating under its "Stage 3 Stay Healthy Guidelines" which state "Gatherings should be limited to 50 or fewer people and adhere to the Physical Distancing and Sanitation Requirements in Section 3 [of the guidelines]"  Gatherings of over 50 may occur under the following:  "Gatherings exceeding the size and capacity limitations specified in Section 1(a) may receive an exemption if the organizer submits a plan for the gathering to the local health district having authority where the gathering is to occur and signs an attestation agreeing to comply with the provisions of the plan submitted to the local health district. The submitted plan and any exempted gatherings should adhere to the Physical Distancing and Sanitation Requirements in Section 3".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503025711/https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-3-stay-healthy-guidelines/

notes_H7: "Starting April 5, there will be no prioritization of any group of people. All Idahoans aged 16 and older, regardless of their age, medical condition, or occupation, will be able to receive the COVID-19 vaccine."   Pfizer, Moderna, J&J    Link: https://archive.fo/g03b6

name: Illinois
notes_C1: On April 23rd, all public high schools are allowed to return to in-person classrooms in Chicago. "High school students on Monday returned to in-person classrooms in Chicago for the first time in more than a year. The Chicago Teachers Union voted to approve a plan to reopen high schools, the union said Sunday, three days after the deal was approved overwhelmingly by the CTU’s House of Delegates."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210422055322/https://www.chicagotribune.com/coronavirus/ct-aud-covid-19-pandemic-chicago-illinois-news-20210419-24u4djrbqre6vfg5lkc7crigjy-story.html
notes_C2: On April 23rd, "the city of Chicago on Wednesday adopted an anti-retaliation ordinance designed to protect workers who miss time on the job for a COVID-19 vaccination appointment. The ordinance prohibits workers from any adverse employer actions including being fired or seeing schedules maliciously adjusted. The City Council’s actions come as restaurant owners develop their vaccine policies — some are considering making vaccines mandatory for employees. Restaurant and bar workers without pre-existing conditions have been eligible for shots since March 29. The Illinois Restaurant Association has been partnering with restaurants and health care providers to set up clinics so service industry workers could be vaccinated."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210421221759/https://chicago.eater.com/2021/4/21/22396335/chicago-ordinance-covid-workplace-retaliation-shots-time-off
notes_C3: All of Illinois is in Phase 4 "Revitalization" of the state's re-opening framework. In Phase 4, "All gatherings of 50 people or fewer are allowed."   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322182829/https://coronavirus.illinois.gov/s/restore-illinois-phase-4
notes_C4: On April 19th, fully vaccinated diners do not count against Illinois restaurant capacity rules. All adults in Illinois will soon be eligible for vaccinations, and that could have major ramifications for restaurants: Fully vaccinated customers — with proof — won’t count against COVID-19 capacity rules. Under current Phase 4 rules, Chicago’s restaurants and bars are allowed a maximum of 50 customers per indoor dining space or 50 percent of full capacity, whichever is fewer.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326231149/https://chicago.eater.com/2021/3/22/22344263/restaurants-bars-capacity-limit-proof-covid-19-vaccination-pritzker-ramova-theater-restoration
notes_C5: No mention of closing public transit, but: People riding on public transit must comply with Social Distancing Requirements to the greatest extent feasible (stated in executive order by Governor of Illinois).   http://archive.vn/YBkdo
notes_C6: Staying at home is still implied in Chicago’s Tier 2 order.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210124040418/https://wgntv.com/news/coronavirus/city-of-chicago-to-move-to-tier-2-effective-immediately-heres-what-that-means-and-what-will-open/
notes_C7: On April 2nd, CDC updated its guideline that people who are vaccinated do not have to quarantine or get tested for COVID-19 when traveling within the United States.     "The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention updated its guidance to say fully vaccinated people can travel within the U.S. without getting tested for the coronavirus or going into quarantine afterward."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210402215202/https://www.chicagotribune.com/coronavirus/ct-aud-covid-19-pandemic-chicago-illinois-news-20210402-avw6ez72bvaqfhktb5e2e6byc4-story.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On March 5 Executive Order 2021-05 was issued, extending, among other orders, EO 2020-20, related to public assistance benefits.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402150126/https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-05.aspx
notes_E2: On March 18, 2021, the Illinois Commerce Commission unanimously approved consumer protection agreements to help electric, natural gas, water, and sewer residential customers hard hit by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic to mitigate outstanding consumer debt and prevent disconnections before the winter moratorium on disconnections expires on March 31, 2021. Consumers struggling to pay their energy bill must call the utility to receive benefits and prevent disconnection.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210402151910/https://www.icc.illinois.gov/home/covid-19
notes_H1: On March 5th, Illinois launched a public campaign to combat COVID-19 stigma in Black and Latino communities according to Chicago Tribune. Illinois is officially launched a $10 million campaign today.     "In an effort to reach Black and Latino communities that have been hard hit by the coronavirus but have lagged behind the rest of the state on vaccinations, Illinois on Friday launched a $10 million public awareness campaign to combat vaccine hesitancy."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210305222501/https://www.chicagotribune.com/coronavirus/ct-aud-covid-19-pandemic-chicago-illinois-news-20210305-muynutjis5e4pohwuffve2gk2e-story.html
notes_H2: The Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH) has several mobile testing teams that are dispatched to various locations around the state each week to provide COVID-19 testing.  Anyone can be tested, regardless of symptoms or immigration status.  There is no cost to the individual for testing, but they should bring their insurance card if they have one.  However, insurance is not required.  Specimens will be collected using a simple nasal swab.  Drive-through and walk-up testing are both available at most locations.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322190906/https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/news-item.aspx?ReleaseID=22977
notes_H3: In Illinois, contact tracing is primarily carried out by local health department (LHD) staff. Based on contact tracing data provided by the Department of Public Health, most regions of the state have successfully interviewed at least half of all positive cases and their close contacts (positive cases: some as high as 90%; Region 11 is very low at 0.26%. Close contacts reached ranges between 44-92% across the regions).   https://web.archive.org/web/20210322191727/https://www.dph.illinois.gov/covid19/contact-tracing-data?DV=1
notes_H6: On March 18, Gov. J.B. Pritzker reinstated that although Illinois is transitioning to full reopening, masking mandates will still be put in place and that face mask will be required until CDC recommends to not require face masks.     "Illinois will lift its face covering requirement when the CDC recommends it," Pritzker said Thursday, crediting public masking as a primary reason why the state can afford to look ahead to a new reopening phase. "Masks have been one of our best ways to reduce risk in this pandemic, and we won’t be so foolish as to throw away our best weapon heading into the last lap of the fight."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210318183744/https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/illinois-face-mask-mandate-remains-as-state-looks-ahead-to-bridge-phase/2465588/
notes_H7: On April 23rd, Illinois resumed administration of J&J vaccine.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503060029/http://www.dph.illinois.gov/news/illinois-department-public-health-resumes-use-johnson-johnson-covid-19-vaccine

name: Indiana
notes_C1: As of May 3, schools in Indiana are offering in-person learning and a hybrid learning model. Many schools in Indiana are planning for extended summer schools options, due to the pandemic to address learning loss from the pandemic.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503163202/https://in.chalkbeat.org/2021/4/23/22399658/to-address-covid-learning-loss-indianapolis-public-schools-expands-summer-school-options
notes_C2: As of April 27th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426140506/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426042602/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html
notes_C3: On May 1, Gov Holcomb issued the Executive Order 21-12 which is continuation of the county-based measures and restrictions to prevent the spread of COVID-19. As of May 3, this order is still in effect and is due to expire on 31 May 2021. This order states that "local health departments based on the overall spread of COVID-19 within their community or based the color-coded metric for the county, may impose measures and restrictions on gatherings and events, including limiting the size of social gatherings or event by over attendance". While local authorities may still impose restrictions, there are no longer state wide restrictions on public events as set out in previous orders.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503162931/https://www.in.gov/gov/newsroom/executive-orders/
notes_C4: On May 1, Gov Holcomb issued the Executive Order 21-12 which is continuation of the county-based measures and restrictions to prevent the spread of COVID-19. As of May 3, this order is still in effect and is due to expire on 31 May 2021. This order states that "local health departments based on the overall spread of COVID-19 within their community or based the color-coded metric for the county, may impose measures and restrictions on gatherings and events, including limiting the size of social gatherings or event by over attendance". While local authorities may still impose restrictions on limiting the size of social gatherings, it is no longer mandated by the state. However, Hoosiers are still advised in this order to maintain social distancing when mixing with people outside their household and exercise caution at all times.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503162931/https://www.in.gov/gov/newsroom/executive-orders/    Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Edit:    Code changed to 4T (from 2T) because the City of Bloomington still limits private gatherings to 15 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210428041847/https://bloomington.in.gov/covid-19
notes_C5: As of March 29, there are no policies that are directed at closing public transport.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329224943/https://www.in.gov/indot/2436.htm
notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: This is the list of government relief available to businesses and employees. Source is Indiana State government.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210122185851/https://iedc.in.gov/resources/covid-19-updates-resources/home
notes_E2: As of January 4, 2021, according to the Indiana Housing & Community Development website, the rental assistance measures using federal funds were still in effect. Source: https://archive.vn/wqJ4c
notes_H1: As of May 3, the state is still operating a coordinated public health campaign.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405142551/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/
notes_H2: As of May 3, Indiana is still running a comprehensive testing system. Hoosiers do not have to be symptomatic in order to get a test. These tests can be obtained can free of charge at community testing sites and tests can be obtained from local health care providers.      Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326211459/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/2524.htm
notes_H3: As of May 3, the Indiana Department of Health is still running a comprehensive contact tracing system.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405143159/https://www.coronavirus.in.gov/contact-tracing/
notes_H6: As of May 3, Executive Order 21-12 issued by Gov. Holcomb is still in effect and will remain in effect until May 31. This order is continuation of the county-based measures and restrictions to prevent the spread of COVID-19. This new order states that mask wearing is only mandatory in all state buildings and facilities, all vaccination and COVID-19 testing sites and at K-12 educational facilities. In all other public locations, mask wearing is now encouraged rather than mandated.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503162931/https://www.in.gov/gov/newsroom/executive-orders/

Indoors, a facility may choose to operate at 75 percent capacity while enforcing six feet of social distancing or at 100 percent capacity with masking required and enforced. notes_H1: no policy change.
notes_H2: no policy change.     Mobile testing for COVID-19 in Southwest Louisiana will now include two locations, both with access to rapid COVID-19 testing through Cue Health. Cue offers COVID-19 molecular point-of-care testing with results in 20 minutes. Both sites will continue to offer laboratory molecular testing through the Louisiana Department of Health Lab or Quest Diagnostics. Individuals will have the option of choosing between PCR or rapid testing.     unable to archive: https://ldh.la.gov/index.cfm/newsroom/detail/6111
notes_H3: no policy change.
notes_H6: no policy change made. Announcement made by Gov. Edwards on upcoming changes to COVID policy to go into effect April 28th (please note these are changes made to the state level, New Orleans has been enforcing stricter rules, code may not change based on what is announced):    Following months of sustained improvement in COVID hospitalizations and an increase in the supply and availability of vaccines, Gov. John Bel Edwards announced that some mitigation measures will be eased and, starting Wednesday, April 28, the statewide mask mandate will be lifted.    Mask policies in Louisiana will be set by local leaders and business owners. Under the Governor’s new public health order, masks will still be required on public transit and in state government buildings, K-12 schools, early childhood education centers, colleges and universities, and healthcare facilities.    State agencies may choose to opt-out of the mask mandate for state-owned buildings in writing to the Secretary of the Louisiana Department of Health and also must inform people entering the building that masks are not mandatory. All state agencies in the Governor’s cabinet and under the Governor’s authority will keep their mask mandates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501113114/https://gov.louisiana.gov/index.cfm/newsroom/detail/3089
notes_H7: no policy change.     The Louisiana Department of Health will resume use of the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine, following a decision late Friday by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Following a thorough safety review, including two meetings of the CDC’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, the FDA and CDC have determined that the recommended temporary pause of the use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine in the U.S. should be lifted and use of the vaccine should resume. LDH has notified all providers that they may resume administering the Johnson & Johnson vaccine immediately and encourages all Louisianans to take advantage of the available vaccines, so the state can continue to slow the spread of COVID-19 and put the pandemic in its rearview.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210424185318/https://ldh.la.gov/index.cfm/newsroom/detail/6121

name: Massachusetts
notes_C1: No change.    "All Massachusetts elementary schools will be fully in-person by May 3, state says"    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501194339/https://www.masslive.com/coronavirus/2021/03/all-massachusetts-elementary-schools-will-be-fully-in-person-by-may-3-state-says.html
notes_C2: No change. Still in Phase IV, Step 1.    MA plans to move into Phase IV, Step 2 on May 10.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501195058/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/reopening-massachusetts    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501195144/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/reopening-when-can-my-business-reopen
notes_C3: No change. Still in Phase IV, Step 1.    "Effective Monday, March 22, all communities in Massachusetts will move into Step 1 of Phase IV of the state’s reopening plan. This will open a range of previously closed business sectors under tight capacity restrictions that are expected to be adjusted over time if favorable trends in the public health data continue. Effective on the planned advancement to Step 1 of Phase IV, the following large capacity sports and entertainment venues will be permitted to operate at a strict 12% capacity limit after submitting a plan to the Department of Public Health (DPH):    Indoor and outdoor stadiums  Arenas  Ballparks  Also effective on March 22, gathering limits for event venues and in public settings will increase to 100 people indoors and 150 people outdoors. Outdoor gatherings at private residences and in private backyards will remain at a maximum of 25 people, with indoor house gatherings remaining at 10 people.    Additionally, dance floors will be permitted at weddings and other events only, and overnight summer camps will be allowed to operate this coming summer. Exhibition and convention halls may also begin to operate, following gatherings limits and event protocols. Other Phase IV sectors must continue to remain closed."    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501195058/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/reopening-massachusetts    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501195435/https://www.mass.gov/news/baker-polito-administration-announces-transition-to-phase-iv-of-reopening-plan
notes_C4: No change. Still in Phase IV, Step 1.    "Gathering limits for event venues and in public settings are currently 100 people indoors and 150 people outdoors. Outdoor gatherings at private residences and in private backyards remain at a maximum of 25 people, with indoor house gatherings remaining at 10 people."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501195058/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/reopening-massachusetts
notes_C5: No change.    "Due to the COVID-19 outbreak, many transit authorities have made adaptations to their regular routes, schedules, and procedures. If you plan to make a trip by public transit, please check your transit authority's website or social media accounts to get the most up-to-date information.    In accordance with the Governor's Order, all passengers over age 5 must wear a face mask while riding public transit and paratransit services, with exceptions made for certain medical conditions and disabilities. Masks are also recommended for passengers ages 2 through 5."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501195658/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/public-transportation-in-massachusetts
notes_C6: No new stay at home advisory found.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501200240/https://www.nbcboston.com/news/coronavirus/baker-to-tour-gillette-vaccination-site-give-update-on-covid-business-relief-program/2284373/
notes_C7: No change.    "As of Monday, March 22, all visitors entering Massachusetts, including returning residents, are advised to quarantine for 10 days upon their arrival.  Travelers in the following categories are exempt from this quarantine advisory:    Travelers who have received a negative COVID-19 result on a test administered not more than 72 hours prior to their arrival in Massachusetts.  Travelers may also test out of the quarantine advisory after arrival in Massachusetts, as long as they quarantine until receiving a negative test result.  Anyone who is entering Massachusetts for fewer than 24 hours  Anyone who is returning to Massachusetts after being out of the State for fewer than 24 hours  Workers who enter Massachusetts to perform critical infrastructure functions (as specified by the Federal Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency) during required commuting to or from work and while at work.  Travelers who are fully vaccinated (i.e. who have received two doses of either the Moderna or Pfizer COVID-19 vaccines OR who have received a single dose of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, 14 days or more ago) and who do not have symptoms.  All travelers are encouraged to consult and follow the CDC’s guidelines and requirements for travel."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501200417/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-advisory

The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7." Please contact the site prior to arrival.    Learn about the free drive-through Express COVID-19 Testing Sites in Massachusetts." notes_H3: No change.    "The Commonwealth of Massachusetts created the COVID-19 Community Tracing program to help support local health departments from every community in their contact tracing work. The program focuses on reaching out to people who have tested positive for COVID-19 and the contacts they have been close to, making sure they have the support they need to isolate or quarantine. When the MA COVID Team calls, you can do your part by answering the phone and providing helpful information that will help flatten and reduce the curve in Massachusetts."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501205115/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/learn-about-the-community-tracing-collaborative
notes_H6: "Face masks will now only be required outside in public when it’s not possible to socially distance — or when required for other reasons, including at outdoor events. Face coverings will still be required at all times in indoor public places, including stores.    Face coverings will also continue to be required at all times at events, whether held indoors or outdoors and whether held in a public space or private home, except when eating or drinking.    At smaller gatherings in private homes, face coverings are recommended but not required. The $300 fine that had been put in place as an enforcement mechanism has also been eliminated.    The mask mandate was put in place when coronavirus cases were soaring last fall, but hospitalizations and COVID cases have been declining. Additionally, Massachusetts is the first state in the country in which two-thirds of all adults have received their first dose."    Context: "The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention unveiled new guidance on outdoor mask-wearing Tuesday that suggests fully vaccinated people don’t have to wear a mask outside unless they’re in a large group."    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501210140/https://www.nbcboston.com/news/local/mask-off-outdoor-face-coverings-no-longer-required-friday/2368314/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501210008/https://www.mass.gov/news/mask-up-massachusetts
notes_H7: A,B,C:    All individuals over the age of 16 are eligible for a vaccine.    Moderna and Pfizer vaccines are being administered. The state has also resumed administering Johnson & Johnson vaccines.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501210600/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/massachusetts-covid-19-vaccination-phases    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501210750/https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-vaccine-frequently-asked-questions    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501210816/https://www.nbcboston.com/news/local/mass-to-get-thousands-of-johnson-johnson-vaccines-this-week/2364197/

name: Maryland
notes_C1: As of May 4, 2021, there has been no policy change. “Washington County Public Schools has been in the fourth phase of its “Return to Learn” plan since Feb. 16. In this phase, students are able to attend in-person classes five days a week while distance learning is offered to those who do not wish to return to the classroom yet.” Additionally, there are currently 43 schools in the state reporting COVID-19 outbreaks.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504200131if_/https://www.heraldmailmedia.com/story/news/education/2021/04/24/md-schools-face-covid-cases-as-students-return-to-classrooms/43741917/
notes_C2: There were no changes to Maryland's policy on workplace closures between 20th and 30th April 2021.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210503162350/https://governor.maryland.gov/recovery/
notes_C3: As of May 4, 2021, there has been no policy change. This indicator remains coded as 1G.
notes_C4: As of May 5th, 2021, there has been no policy change. Executive Order 21-04-21-01, which was passed on 21st April 2021, sets maximum occupancy of venues at 50%. This indicator remains at 3G.     Source: https://archive.vn/jeIvs
notes_C5: As of May 5, 2021, there has been no policy change. According to the Maryland Transit Authority website, all services are running, though facial coverings and social distancing are required on public transport. This indicator remains coded as 0.     Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210505195457/https://www.mta.maryland.gov/coronavirus
notes_C6: As of 3rd May 2021, there are no official stay at home orders in place in Maryland. Residents are advised to stay at home if they are sick.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210427221116/https://covidlink.maryland.gov/content/faqs/
notes_C7: As of 3rd May 2021, Maryland has no specific controls on movement between states. Marylanders are still encouraged to postpone or avoid travel wherever possible.     Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210503162350/https://governor.maryland.gov/recovery/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210427221116/https://covidlink.maryland.gov/content/faqs/
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: The Maryland RELIEF Act, which was signed into law on 15th February 2021, provides direct stimulus payments to low- and middle-income Maryland families. As these stimulus payments comprise $500 for families and $300 for individuals, this indicator moves to 1A.     Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210503155324/https://www.marylandtaxes.gov/reliefact/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210503155707/https://governor.maryland.gov/reliefact/
notes_E2: Original note from Jay Harley:    As of February 15th 2021, financial relief remains in place under the updated Maryland RELIEF act, including several provisions intended to provide immediate economic relief to eligible Maryland residents and small businesses, including state-issued "economic impact" stimulus payments for low and moderate-income taxpayers. Webpage here:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301222345/https://www.dllr.state.md.us/finance/consumers/frcovid.shtml
notes_H1: Maryland's ongoing COVID-19 public information campaign can be seen in, among other things, its state Twitter account.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210503153743/https://twitter.com/MDHealthDept/status/1252601186454245377
notes_H2: The Covid-19 Testing in Maryland webpage indicates that testing is still widespread in the state. On 29th April 2021, a two-week mobile testing programme began to operate at two Walmart stores in Salisbury and Hagerstown. "Free rapid point-of-care (POC) antigen testing, with PCR confirmatory results, will be offered without appointments needed. This is part of a two-week pilot to increase testing opportunities in underserved areas nationwide."     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210503160126/https://coronavirus.maryland.gov/pages/symptoms-testing
notes_H3: From Maryland's covidLINK homepage, it appears that contact tracing is still in effect in the state as of 27th April 2021, although it is unclear exactly how effective it is.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210427214139/https://covidlink.maryland.gov/content/answer-the-call/
notes_H6: On 28th April 2021, Governor Larry Hogan lifted the requirement for facial coverings to be worn in outdoor public spaces. They are still required in indoor public spaces, so this indicator moves to 2G.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210502085417/https://governor.maryland.gov/2021/04/28/governor-hogan-lifts-outdoor-mask-mandate-ends-restrictions-on-outdoor-dining/
notes_H7: As of 1st May 2021, all Marylanders over the age of 16 can book an appointment for their first dose of a COVID-19 vaccine. The last of 13 new mass vaccination sites opened on 30th April 2021 in Howard County.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210503162350/https://governor.maryland.gov/recovery/

name: Maine
notes_C1: The April 23rd assessment of Maine's counties rated all of them as green except for Androscoggin, Kennebec, Oxford, and Somerset. A yellow rating does not necessarily mean that a school has to switch over to remote learning, but that they "may consider hybrid instructional models". Given this, this indicator remains at 1G.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210426181220/https://www.maine.gov/doe/framework/part-I/
notes_C2: As of April 27th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426140506/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426042602/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html
notes_C3: As of 26th April 2021, there have been no specific updates to Maine's policy on public events. The continuing 1G indicator therefore reflects Maine's ongoing state of emergency, which was extended on 14th April 2021 to last until at least 13th May 2021.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419224044/https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/news/governor-mills-continues-state-civil-emergency-maine-fights-covid-19-2021-04-14
notes_C4: As of 26th April 2021, Maine's restrictions on indoor and outdoor gatherings are still in place. They are due to change on 24th May 2021.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419224158/https://www.maine.gov/covid19/moving-maine-forward
notes_C5: As of 26th April 2021, the Greater Portland Metro system is running, with requirements that passengers and staff wear face coverings at all times.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210426182201/https://gpmetro.org/AlertCenter.aspx?AID=Health-Advisories-Service-Updates-Update-285
notes_C6: As of 26th April 2021, it is still recommended that those at greatest risk from COVID-19 limit their time outside the home.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210422183341/https://www.maine.gov/covid19/
notes_C7: As of 26th April 2021, Maine's requirement for out-of-state visitors (except the states listed below) to have a recent negative test or quarantine for 10 days upon arrival in the state are still in place. Therefore this indicator remains at 2G.    States exempt from testing requirements:  New Hampshire  Vermont  Massachusetts  Connecticut   Rhode Island    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210422183341/https://www.maine.gov/covid19/
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: As of 26th April 2021, Maine's Emergency Rental Assistance Program is still running. Therefore this indicator remains at 1.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210426181516/https://www.mainehousing.org/programs-services/rental/rentaldetail/covid-19-rental-relief-program
notes_H1: As of 26th April 2021, Maine's COVID-19 homepage continues to provide information to the public.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210422183341/https://www.maine.gov/covid19/
notes_H2: As of 26th April 2021, COVID-19 testing is still widely available in Maine, with anybody over the age of 12 months able to get a test without a physician's referral.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210422183341/https://www.maine.gov/covid19/
notes_H3: As of 26th April 2021, it appears that Maine's contact tracing system is still in operation.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210422224533/https://www.maine.gov/dhhs/mecdc/infectious-disease/epi/airborne/coronavirus/contact-tracing.shtml
notes_H6: As of 27 April, Governor Janet Mills announces that Maine residents are no longer required to wear a mask outdoors, based on CDC recommendations that the risk of transmission outdoors is low. Masks are still required indoors, however. Code moves down to 2G.    See the announcement:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503210226/https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/news/maine-updates-public-health-guidance-use-face-coverings-outdoor-public-settings-2021-04-27
notes_H7: As of 26th April 2021, Maine is still administering vaccinations to all over-16s. On April 18th 2021, Governor Mills announced that half of all over-16s in Maine had received at least one dose. Administering of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine is still paused, so Pfizer and Moderna are being used.     Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210423031548/https://www.maine.gov/covid19/vaccines    http://web.archive.org/web/20210419141452/https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/news/governor-mills-announces-half-maine-people-16-and-older-have-received-least-one-dose-covid-19

name: Michigan
notes_C1: On Apr. 9 Gov. Whitmer urged high schools to temporarily halt in-person learning and residents to restrict their activities, due to a surge in Covid-19 cases. However, Gov. Whitmer stated that this was not a legal order or restriction, so the coding does not change from the previous (2T).    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210410235223/https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/09/covid-michigan-gov-whitmer-urges-residents-to-restrict-activity-as-new-cases-overwhelm-state-health-system.html
notes_C2: Employers must require employees to perform their work remotely unless their work cannot feasibly be completed. Masks, social distancing, and daily screenings for COVID-19 are required. Non-essential businesses such as cosmetologists remain open.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426120742/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-100467_100913---,00.html
notes_C3: As of 5 April, the Gatherings and Face mask Order re-issued by the MDHHS on 19 March is still in effect. This order states that gatherings are prohibited at entertainment facilities and recreational facilities unless a number of social distancing, capacity limitations and mask wearing guidelines are followed.   Indoor gatherings are prohibited at residential venues, except where no more than 15 persons from no more than 3 households are gathered. Such gatherings should be held consistent with guidance issued by the Department of Health and Human Services for such gatherings; and are prohibited at non-residential venues, except where no more than 25 persons are gathered. Outdoor gatherings are permitted only as follows: At residential venues, where 50 or fewer persons are gathered; At non-residential venues, where 300 or fewer persons are gathered.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210419203003/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-554922--,00.html
notes_C4: On April 19 the Gatherings and Face Mask Order was updated, given that "In the past eight weeks, spread of COVID-19 has risen nearly 400% amongst persons aged 10-19. As of April 8, local health departments had reported 312 new and ongoing outbreaks among K-12 schools, with 48 of those outbreaks reported in the week prior." However, the size of indoor and outdoor gatherings has not changed. This Order will be in effect until May 24, 2021.   "Indoor gatherings: Are prohibited at residential venues, except where no more than 15 persons from no more than 3 households are gathered. Such gatherings should be held consistent with guidance issued by the Department of Health and Human Services for such gatherings; and  Are prohibited at non-residential venues, except where no more than 25 persons are gathered. Outdoor gatherings are permitted only as follows:  At residential venues, where 50 or fewer persons are gathered; At non-residential venues, where 300 or fewer persons are gathered.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419205448/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-557116--,00.html
notes_C5: The Detroit Department of Transportation states that a mask is still required on the bus under federal law, passengers must stay 6 feet apart, avoid riding the bus if people feel ill and to use the hand sanitiser provided.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405133116/https://detroitmi.gov/departments/detroit-department-transportation/responding-covid-19
notes_C6: As of April 5, there is no mandated stay at home requirements but the MDHHS still reminds people that socialising with people outside your home is risky and that precautions should be taken.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405132414/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus
notes_C7: The "Pure Michigan Pledge" is a part of Michigan's tourism efforts to showcase businesses who have a "commitment to upholding disinfecting and social distancing protocols." Guidelines for travelers encourage them to follow CDC guidelines and other state and local public health safety measures.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210419212732/https://www.michigan.org/guidelinesfortravelers
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: Pandemic Unemployment Assistance (PUA) and Pandemic Emergency Unemployment Compensation (PEUC) are extended through September 4, 2021. Pandemic Unemployment Compensation, the additional $300 per week for anyone receiving unemployment benefits, according to the Michigan Department of Labor and Economic Opportunity's Unemployment Insurance Agency.   In late February, the U.S. Dept. of Labor issued guidance expanding PUA eligibility to include three COVID-19 related reasons under which an individual may self-certify when directly affected by COVID-19 including:  "Individuals who refuse to return to work that is unsafe or to accept an offer of new work that is unsafe (meaning it is not in compliance with local, state or national health and safety standards directly related to COVID-19) Certain individuals who provide services to educational institutions or educational service agencies and are fully or partially unemployed as a direct result of COVID-19. Individuals experiencing a reduction of hours or a temporary or permanent layoff as a direct result of COVID-19. The additional eligibility provisions apply retroactively to the beginning of the PUA program for those who filed before Dec. 27, 2020."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419232201/https://www.michigan.gov/leo/0,5863,7-336-94422_97241---,00.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419232504/https://www.michigan.gov/leo/0,5863,7-336-94422_97241_89982_92608_63224_105333---,00.html
notes_E2: Rental assistance is available for Michiganders. The City of Detroit implemented a water shutoff moratorium that is in effect until 2022. A temporary statewide ban on water shutoffs at occupied homes arising from unpaid bills is set to automatically expire on March 31. No other formal moratoriums on utility shutoffs have been issued by the state. The Michigan Public Service Commission ended other utility shutoff protections in July 2020. The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services has issued payments to the accounts of low-income customers to help them continue paying their energy bills during the coronavirus pandemic. Individuals may be eligible for utility assistance via CERA. Mortgage/Foreclosure Relief: The Michigan Department of Health and Human Services offers homeowners up to $2,000 in emergency assistance with mortgage payments, property taxes, and other housing-related items.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419233448/https://www.michiganradio.org/post/water-shutoff-moratorium-ends-march-31-extension-possible  https://www.justia.com/covid-19/50-state-covid-19-resources/eviction-mortgage-foreclosure-relief-during-covid-19-50-state-resource/#michigan
notes_H1: Michigan Department of Health and Human Services continues to regularly update its Covid-19 website. Michigan created a Covid-19 vaccine website with FAQ, registration, and more. See here:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210419235759/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_103214---,00.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210420000233/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus
notes_H2: MDHHS is encouraging anyone who meets the testing criteria to get tested. Free testing is widely available, including at federally qualified health centers and major retail pharmacies. For more detailed information on testing prioritization, see archived link.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210420210237/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98163-530157--,00.html
notes_H3: Comprehensive contact tracing is in place. Customers are required to provide information for tracing purposes at many businesses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426120742/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-100467_100913---,00.html
notes_H6: The Gatherings and Face Mask Order was updated on April 19 by the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services (MDHHS), expanding the mask requirements to apply to children ages 2-4 (previously age 5 was the youngest).   https://web.archive.org/web/20210420001719/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-557116--,00.html
notes_H7: All people ages 16 and up are eligible to receive vaccination. (Pfizer, Moderna). Use of the Johnson and Johnson vaccine was paused in Michigan on April 13, 2021.    Sources:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210313231928/https://www.uofmhealth.org/coronavirus/covid19-vaccine-phases-progress  https://web.archive.org/web/20210418064559/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98158-556815--,00.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210420003225/https://www.michigan.gov/documents/coronavirus/MI_COVID-19_Vaccination_Prioritization_Guidance_2152021_716344_7.pdf

name: Minnesota
notes_C1: As of May 3rd, 6% of the schools in Minnesota adopted distance learning, 53% offered in-person learning, and the rest implemented hybrid/ combination learning.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503071147/https://analytics.education.state.mn.us/t/MDEPublic/views/MN_Safe_Learning_Model/Dashboard?iframeSizedToWindow=true&%3Aembed=y&%3AshowAppBanner=false&%3Adisplay_count=no&%3AshowVizHome=no
notes_C2: The Stay Safe Plan effective April 15 recommending but not requiring work from home is still in place.     https://archive.vn/K6FaG
notes_C3: The Stay Safe Plan regarding capacity limit for indoor and outdoor events updated on April 1st is still in effect.    https://archive.ph/Yu02Y
notes_C4: The Stay Safe Plan regarding social settings (limiting indoor gatherings to 15 people) updated on March 15th is still in effect.    https://archive.ph/Yu02Y
notes_C5: Capacity limits on Metro Transit updated on April 5th is still in effect.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503074605/https://www.metrotransit.org/covid19
notes_C6: As of April 15th, there hadn’t been any new Covid-19 regulation since April 1st.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419072440/https://mn.gov/covid19/stay-safe/stay-safe-plan/index.jsp
notes_C7: As of April 12th, Minnesota Health Department still recommended people who had traveled from out-of-state to quarantine for 14 days.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210401232134/https://www.aarp.org/travel/travel-tips/safety/info-2020/state-quarantine-guide.html  Guidelines: http://web.archive.org/web/20210410061104/https://www.health.state.mn.us/diseases/coronavirus/quarguide.pdf
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of April 19th, Pandemic Emergency Unemployment Compensation (PEUC), Pandemic Unemployment Assistance (PUA), and supplemental payments ($300 per week) were still active. These benefits are set to expire on September 2021.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419083323/https://www.uimn.org/applicants/needtoknow/news-updates/federal-stimulus-legislation.jsp
notes_E2: As of April 13th, the federal moratorium on evictions was still in place. The moratorium is set to expire on June 30th.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210419062920/https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/29/success/cdc-eviction-order-extended/index.html
notes_H1: Minnesota Department of Health continues to provide information on COVID-19 data, testing and vaccines through their media platforms.    https://archive.ph/NnEn2
notes_H2: Minnesota Department of Health website continues to provide information on free testing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503080658/https://www.health.state.mn.us/diseases/coronavirus/testsites/index.html
notes_H3: Minnesota Dept of Health's homepage advertises case investigation and contact tracing jobs:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210201225254/https://www.health.state.mn.us/about/jobs.html
notes_H6: On April 15th, Governor Tim Walz issued EO 21-19, which extended EO 20-01 until May 14th. This means that mask mandate under EO 20-81 was still in place. Individuals must wear mask in public/ business indoor settings and public transportation    EO 21-19: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419081513/https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2021-19%20Final%20%28003%29_tcm1055-476482.pdf   EO 20-81: http://web.archive.org/web/20210329083209/https://www.leg.mn.gov/archive/execorders/20-81.pdf
notes_H7: Starting March 30th, Minnesotans 16+ are eligible for vaccination. The state urges health care providers to vaccinate individuals who are at risk of getting Covid-19.     Source: https://archive.fo/fvFSA

name: Missouri
notes_C1: On March 24, the University of Missouri published a press release about workers. Dear University faculty and staff,    Throughout this last year, you have proven yourselves resilient in a time of great uncertainty and steady change. We so appreciate your willingness to step up and keep us going.    Thankfully, effective – and increasingly available – COVID-19 vaccines, along with a decrease in active cases in our region, usher in new possibilities for how we can interact.    Next Monday (March 29), all of you, as higher education faculty and staff (including student employees), will be eligible to receive a COVID-19 vaccine. We strongly encourage you to sign up for a vaccine appointment. Please see our vaccine page here for links to options, which includes information to make an appointment as dates become available at our Faurot Field vaccine site. There, dedicated MU Health Care teams have already vaccinated nearly 23,000 people.    Over the last several months, many of you safely returned to in-person work, following our COVID-19 guidelines. Meanwhile in our community, public schools have announced plans to shift to full in-person attendance in early April and this week, Boone County relaxed public health orders. We expect this progress to continue as we approach fall and our plans to resume full-capacity classes and activities here at Mizzou.    As another step toward resuming our pre-pandemic lives, we ask faculty and staff who have not yet returned to in-person work to do so by May 17. Faculty on 9-month appointments without duties over the summer should plan to return in August. We are sending this message in advance to give you and your supervisor time to make a transition plan if needed.    As more faculty and staff return, we remain committed to sustaining a safe community. Social distancing and face covering requirements will continue until public health guidance changes. Supervisors will need to ensure work settings meet office safety expectations and consult with Campus Facilities if work spaces need modification.    We know ongoing efforts to maximize our resources, including the recent announcement to close buildings, mean some in-person offices will not be the same. In addition, we realize, in some settings, social distancing is not possible with a full in-person return and that factor should be considered in any transition plan. If you witness an unsafe situation at work related to our COVID-19 protocols, you should let your supervisor know or submit a concern here.    Through this transition, we expect to retain some of our COVID-era practices, as we found some enhanced our work. In some circumstances, supervisors may decide flexible work arrangements will best fit the environment and the work needed to support the university’s mission. If so, your supervisor will initiate, revise or extend a telework arrangement. The form is available on our Working Through COVID-19 webpage and will need to be submitted by May 17.    We know our Tigers are anxious to enjoy a “more normal” experience in the fall, which will of course adhere to the advice of our medical experts, local public health officials, and CDC guidance. Our Show Me Renewal site will stay current with any changes along the way. There, you can also find the latest updates on the process for planning events. We see this step as a sign of hope for our university as we return to more in-person activity to serve our students, our community, and our state.    Thank you to everyone for your tremendous efforts during this extraordinary time. We are grateful to reach this point and for the rest of our community to join us on our beautiful campus.    Tigers Support Tigers!    Mun Choi, Ph.D.  President, University of Missouri    https://web.archive.org/web/20210330134539/https://president.missouri.edu/messages/full-in-person-work-return-by-5-17/
notes_C2: As of April 25, St. Louis City and Kansas City continue to implement restrictions for businesses, including capacity restrictions, social distancing requirements, and facial covering requirements.  https://archive.fo/pqTY1 https://web.archive.org/web/20210426104420/https://www.kcmo.gov/city-hall/departments/health/coronavirus-covid-19-kcmo-information-and-response/reopen
notes_C3: Boone County issued Order No. 2020-21C, and the City of Columbia issued Order No. 2020-21, effective March 24. Sports and sporting events are allowed, but participants must remain in stable groups and spectators must follow social distancing and mask-wearing requirements.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327043037/https://www.como.gov/wp-content/uploads/Health-Order-2020-21c-Boone-County.pdf https://web.archive.org/web/20210405132729/https://www.como.gov/wp-content/uploads/Health-Order-2020-21-City-of-Columbia.pdf     As of April 4, the latest health order in St. Louis County is still the Fourth Amended Safer At Home Order, which requires any outdoor event at 50% capacity that exceeds 500 people to submit a plan for approval by the Department of Health.    https://archive.fo/hPLLl    The St. Louis Auto Show taking place downtown at America’s Center and the St. Charles Home Show at the St. Charles Convention Center represent two of the earliest large-scale events to return in the area during the COVID-19 era. The show will run from April 10-11.    https://archive.fo/oMkvS    Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Edit:    Code changed to 1T (from 2T) since sporting events are allowed to occur with COVID-19 precautionary measures. Also, the interpretation guide advises coding at the 1 level if public venues/mass gatherings are limited by percent occupancy restrictions.
notes_C4: As of April 25, the restrictions on private indoor gatherings in St. Louis City continues to be 10 people. There is no upper limit on gatherings in Kansas City, provided masking and social distancing guidelines are followed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426104959/https://www.stlouis-mo.gov/government/departments/health/communicable-disease/covid-19/orders/health-commissioner-order-15.cfm https://web.archive.org/web/20210426105048/https://www.visitkc.com/coronavirus
