The latest pandemic-related executive order was enacted on November 19, 2020.    Executive Orders: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125122922/https://governor.mo.gov/actions/executive-orders   Legislative Actions: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125123621/https://governor.mo.gov/actions/legislative-actions   Proclamations: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125123830/https://governor.mo.gov/actions/proclamations
notes_C6: St. Louis County Department of Public Health issued its Fifth Amended Safer at Home Order to take effect on April 9, 2021, rescinding and replacing the March 8, 2021 Order. People may not leave their residences except for specific reasons, which explicitly do not include social gatherings unless with family or those that are part of their support bubble.  https://archive.fo/C3rFZ
notes_C7: The executive Order 21-04 extending the hours of service exemption for commercial motor vehicles transporting residential heating fuel is continuing. Therefore, no change for C7.
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On March 19,oday, Governor Mike Parson announced that the Missouri Department of Revenue is extending the state individual tax filing and payment deadline for the 2020 tax year from April 15, 2021, to May 17, 2021.    “As our state continues recovering from COVID-19, we understand that many Missourians are still feeling the effects of the past year,” Governor Parson said. “Extending the filing and payment deadline by one month will provide additional relief to Missouri families and tax professionals as they work to meet their obligations during what has already been a challenging tax season.”      This decision mirrors Wednesday’s announcement by the U.S. Treasury Department and the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) that individual taxpayers would receive automatic extensions to file and pay federal income tax for the 2020 tax year. The IRS has said it will issue formal guidance in the coming days.    The Department of Revenue will automatically provide this filing and payment relief, so filers do not need to take any action to qualify.    Guidance on extension to file and pay individual income tax:    Filing deadline extended: The deadline to file individual income tax returns has been extended from April 15, 2021, to May 17, 2021.  Payment relief for individuals: The deadline to pay taxes owed on individual income tax returns with a due date of April 15, 2021, has been extended until May 17, 2021.  This relief applies to individual taxpayers, including those who pay self-employment tax. However, it does not apply to estimated tax payments that are due on April 15, 2021; that deadline has not changed.  Penalties and interest will begin to accrue on any remaining unpaid balances as of May 17, 2021. Individuals that file their return and pay their balance by May 17, 2021, will automatically avoid interest and penalties on the tax paid by May 17.  Customers may still ask for an extension of time to file their individual income taxes. With that extension, the return will not be due until October 15, 2021. However, any payments must still be made by May 17, 2021.  Earlier this year, the IRS announced that the nation’s 2021 electronic tax filing season would begin on February 12. On that date, the IRS began accepting and processing e-filed 2020 tax year returns. Since e-filed state returns are first sent to the IRS, the Department also began accepting and processing e-filed returns for the 2020 tax year on February 12.    “With a delayed start and recent tax code changes, this tax season is a particularly complicated one,” said Director of Revenue Ken Zellers. “For Missourians who have yet to file, we strongly encourage you to file electronically and use direct deposit, as it will result in the most accurate return and the fastest refund. We appreciate your patience as we navigate this tax season together, and we stand ready to assist you in any way we can.”    Department of Revenue online services and resources:    The Department’s Tax Return Status Tracker allows customers to enroll in automatic text and email alerts that are sent each time the status of their return is updated. Customers need their Social Security number, filing status, and anticipated refund or balance due to enroll and must re-enroll each year.  Get answers 24/7 by reviewing the Personal Tax FAQs or with the help of the Department’s chatbot, DORA, a virtual assistant programmed to respond to common taxation, motor vehicle, and driver licensing questions.  Email questions to income@dor.mo.gov.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326185020/https://governor.mo.gov/press-releases/archive/governor-parson-announces-individual-tax-filing-and-payment-deadline
notes_E2: Mayor Lyda Krewson today announced that City of St. Louis residents who need help staying in their homes and keeping their utilities on during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic can apply for rental and utility assistance through the State of Missouri beginning Thursday, April 1. Since two major cities have rental assistance in place (St. Louis & Kansas City), I have changed the coding from 0 “None” to 1 “Narrow” relief.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405130357/https://www.stlouis-mo.gov/government/departments/mayor/news/rental-utility-assistance-apr-2021.cfm https://archive.fo/O7oVh
notes_H1: As of April 17, Missouri is preparing to launch a $5 million ad campaign to urge residents to get the coronavirus vaccine. Called Stronger Together, the campaign will begin next month and will provide vaccination information through radio, TV, print and social media messages.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210417195927/https://ktvo.com/news/local/missouri-to-begin-5m-covid-19-vaccination-campaign
notes_H2: On April 30, testing continues to be one of the most effective tools in the fight to contain the virus that causes COVID-19 and move past the pandemic.      Those who should get tested include those experiencing symptoms of COVID-19, those who have had close contact with someone with confirmed COVID-19 (unless fully vaccinated or tested positive for COVID-19 within the past 3 months), those with household contact, those who have taken part in activities that put them at higher risk of infection, and those who have been recommended for testing by their healthcare provider or health department. Many camps, events and some forms of travel have moved to requiring evidence of a negative test result prior to participation.    Testing capacity has grown significantly over the past year, and testing efforts have continuously evolved to meet existing needs.    Now, there are tests that have been authorized by the FDA for at-home usage. Those who need to be tested for COVID-19 and can’t get tested by a healthcare provider can consider using either a self-collection kit or a self-test that can be performed anywhere. Self-collection kits and tests are available either by prescription or over the counter in a pharmacy or retail store without a prescription. Currently available self-collection kits and tests are used for the detection of current infection. These tests either require a nasal or saliva specimen.    The availability of these tests increases access to testing which results in the ability to take appropriate public health action. However, following the self-collection directions carefully is important for the validity of the result. It is also important to follow directions for reporting of the test results as it ensures the continuity of public health surveillance and mitigation efforts    The State continues to offer community testing events in areas throughout the state in a regular weekly cadence. A new regular event in Branson has been added to the schedule. Community testing events are free COVID-19 testing options that are available to anyone without any specific reason needed for the testing.     No pre-registration or appointment is needed, and patients do not need to be Missouri residents to be tested. A government-issued ID is not required, but if available will shorten the onsite registration process. The test used at these community testing events is a PCR test done by an anterior nares swab to determine the presence of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. Once tested, individuals will be notified of results no later than 72 hours from the end of the testing event.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503141703/https://health.mo.gov/news/newsitem/uuid/885a067c-2b1c-480a-a270-18333827f2da/more-covid-19-testing-options-increase-accessibility
notes_H3: On February 26, the Missouri Department of Health & Senior Service published that variants of the COVID-19 virus continue to develop around the world, and scientists in the United States and around the world continue to monitor them for their characteristics as they relate to infectivity, morbidity and response to available vaccines and treatments. At this time, the most concerning virus variants are required to be reported to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC): those that have emerged from the United Kingdom (known as 20I/501Y.V1, VOC 202012/01, or B.1.1.7), South Africa (known as 20H/501Y.V2 or B.1.351) and Brazil (known as 20J/501Y.V3 or P.1). To date, one person has been identified as having the UK variant in Missouri and none with the South African or Brazilian variant. At least 45 states have reported at least one case of the UK variant to the CDC.    Missouri is a national thought leader for its use of sewage analysis to study the prevalence of COVID-19 virus within samples from around the state to monitor prevalence and trends in an aggregated manner. Working with the University of Missouri and Missouri Department of Natural Resources, the Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services (DHSS) recently widened its capacity to do coronavirus viral sequencing to also look at sewage samples from around the state to further enhance surveillance for existing and emerging variants.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210302011210/https://health.mo.gov/news/newsitem/uuid/d831a879-4f93-4b30-a0a0-214d6cd55662/state-continues-to-monitor-covid-19-variant-viruses
notes_H6: As of April 25, Kansas City still requires residents to wear facial coverings in public spaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426104420/https://www.kcmo.gov/city-hall/departments/health/coronavirus-covid-19-kcmo-information-and-response/reopen
notes_H7: On April 27, the Missouri Department of Health and Senior Services (DHSS) launched the Spanish language version of the Missouri Vaccine Navigator, a secure registry tool to assist Missourians in receiving a COVID-19 vaccine. To further assist non-English speaking individuals, additional languages will be offered soon. All Missourians over the age of 16 are now eligible to get a COVID-19 vaccine. (Pfizer is the only vaccine authorized for those aged 16-17).     Approximately 750,000 Missouri residents are currently registered in Missouri Vaccine Navigator, which is powered by Qualtrics. The system allows individuals to register and schedule an appointment for a COVID-19 vaccine by viewing vaccination events throughout the state.     In addition to helping individuals register for a vaccine, the Missouri Vaccine Navigator will remind registrants when it is time to schedule their second dose. Two of the vaccines currently authorized for use (Pfizer and Moderna) require two doses, and the second dose is critical to ensure individual and community protection.    The Missouri Vaccine Navigator also integrates with ShowMeVax, the state’s immunization database for providers. Vaccination events using the Missouri Vaccine Navigator for scheduling enables coordinators to quickly load vaccination administration data into the system and avoid cumbersome data entry.    Once an individual is registered with Missouri Vaccine Navigator, the scheduling platform becomes available and can be accessed as often as needed or until vaccination is achieved.     Those with online accessibility issues are encouraged to call the COVID-19 hotline at 877-435-8411 for registration assistance. Language translation and other services are available to callers.   COVID-19 vaccines are completely free for everyone in the U.S. Get the facts at MOStopsCovid.com.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503141335/https://health.mo.gov/news/newsitem/uuid/aeffb2e5-0c2b-4120-915a-805840921c5b/state-launches-spanish-language-version-of-missouri-vaccine-navigator

name: Mississippi
notes_C1: As of May 3, 2021, Mississippi schools still have the option to choose whether they want to be traditional, virtual, or hybrid, as stated by the Mississippi State Board of Education (SBE).     The University of Mississippi continues to remain open. However, students are not allowed to attend in person class until their quarantine periods are complete.    Links:    School Closure Map by State:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503210407/https://www.edweek.org/leadership/map-where-are-schools-closed/2020/07     SBE Link Updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503210750/https://www.mdek12.org/COVID19     University of Mississippi Links:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503211109/https://coronavirus.olemiss.edu/faq/classes-and-academics/ https://web.archive.org/web/20210503211147/https://www.outreach.olemiss.edu/tupelo//Tupelo_Spring21.pdf
notes_C2: As of April 27th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426140506/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426042602/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html
notes_C3: On April 30th, Executive Order 1551 came into effect. There is no restriction of public events, however it is recommended to limit social events. For this reason C3 is coded 1G.    However, all persons are encouraged to avoid large gatherings, particularly indoor gatherings.    Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430173539/https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1551.pdf
notes_C4: On April 30th, Executive Order 1551 came into effect. There is no restriction on gatherings. For this reason C3 is coded 0.    However, all persons are encouraged to avoid large gatherings, particularly indoor gatherings.    Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430173539/https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1551.pdf
notes_C5: As of May 3, 2021, there are no public transportation closures. The Jackson Transport Authority follow CDC guidelines, requiring all passengers to wear facial coverings and maintain social distancing when possible.    Links:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503211508/https://mijata.org/covid-19-response/
notes_C6: On April 30th, Executive Order 1551 came into effect. There is no stay at home order requirement.     However, all persons are encouraged to stay at home if they feel sick or have any symptoms of COVID-19.    Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430173539/https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1551.pdf
notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of May 3, 2021, the Rental Assistance for Mississippians Program (RAMP) continues (launched March 29, 2021). Eligible households can apply to receive up to 15 months of assistance on payments pertaining to rent or utilities/ home energy costs(e.g., electricity, gas, water and sewer, trash removal, and energy costs).    Links:     RAMP Website Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503211609/https://ms-ramp.com/     Additional Links:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503211738/https://mississippitoday.org/2021/03/29/struggling-renters-in-mississippi-can-now-apply-for-assistance/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503211838/https://www.mshomecorp.com/2021/03/mhc-announces-application-launch-of-rental-assistance-program/
notes_E2: As of April 27th, the eviction moratorium is still in place.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210424154911/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf
notes_H1: As of May 3, 2021, The Mississippi State Department of Health continues to highlight its COVID-19 response on its website.      Links:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503211931/https://msdh.ms.gov/
notes_H2: As of May 3, 2021, all Mississippi residents “can be tested for COVID-19 by local medical providers statewide, or at free testing sites held at various locations around the state. Some providers may require that you have qualifying symptoms before testing.”    There is testing available to college and university students, faculty, or staff, as well as child care facility workers regardless if they are asymptomatic or have symptoms of COVID-19.    Coded as 2 to reflect the policy that anyone who has COVID-19 symptoms can be tested, and that there are many testing centers at which residents can do so.    Link to testing policy page on MS Department of Health site: https://web.archive.org/web/20210501213023/https://msdh.ms.gov/msdhsite/_static/14,21912,420,874.html     Link to special testing groups for COVID-19:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503212451/https://msdh.ms.gov/msdhsite/_static/14,22406,420,874.html
notes_H3: As of May 3, 2021 there is still no indication of expansion or reduction in contact tracing efforts and there is no indication of whether participation in tracing efforts is mandatory. However, 200 contact tracers are reported to be working currently.    Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503212531/https://testandtrace.com/state-data/
notes_H6: On April 30th, Executive Order 1551 came into effect. There is now no facial mask mandate, except for individuals in school buildings or classrooms (with a few exceptions). The mask mandate for individuals in schools will remain for the remainder of the 2020-2021 academic year. Because facial masks are required in schools H6 remains coded as 3T.    In general all persons of Mississippi are still encouraged to wear face coverings “whenever it is not possible to maintain social distancing from persons not in the same household.”    Links:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210430173539/https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1551.pdf     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503211247/https://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/national/texas-lifting-covid-19-mask-mandate-allowing-businesses-to-open-at-100-capacity
notes_H7: As of May 3, 2021, Mississippians aged 16 and older are eligible for vaccination. For this reason H7 is coded as 5G, as it is now universally available. “COVID-19 vaccinations are provided to Mississippi residents only, or to out-of-state residents who work in Mississippi.”     “Persons aged 16 and older can receive the Pfizer vaccine, and those 18 and over can receive the Moderna or Johnson & Johnson vaccines.”    Links:      https://web.archive.org/web/20210502064057/https://msdh.ms.gov/msdhsite/_static/14,22816,420,976.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501213023/https://msdh.ms.gov/msdhsite/_static/14,21912,420,874.html

notes_C8: As of April 27th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426160314/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426010332/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html

notes_H2: No new updates. As of April 26, 2021, the NCDHHS states "If you are experiencing symptoms of COVID-19 or have been exposed to the virus, you should be tested."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426180852/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/about-covid-19/testing/find-my-testing-place
notes_H3: As of April 26, 2021 "There are more than 2,000 full-time and part-time staff supporting contact tracing efforts at the LHD level, including the 1,221 Community Care of North Carolina (CCNC) contact tracers."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426181137/https://covid19.ncdhhs.gov/dashboard/contact-tracing
notes_H6: No new updates. Executive order 204 remains in effect with the state's general mask mandate which enforces facial coverings in public indoor spaces.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426181423/https://governor.nc.gov/news/gov-cooper-announces-north-carolina-will-relax-some-covid-19-restrictions%EF%BB%BF

name: North Dakota
notes_C1: No further evidence of school closures
notes_C2: As of April 27th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426140506/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426042602/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html
notes_C3: Public events allowed to proceed, as risk level is Green - Low statewide, but limited to 75% of normal venue capacity     Smart Restart Plan: https://web.archive.org/web/20210313121332/https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/Additional%20Resources/NDSmartRestartPlan.pdf  Current risk levels: https://web.archive.org/web/20210313121440/https://ndresponse.gov/covid-19-resources/covid-19-business-and-employer-resources/nd-smart-restart/nd-smart-restart-protocols    Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Note:    Code changed to 1G (from 0). The interpretation guide advises coding at the 1 level if public venues/mass gatherings are limited by percent occupancy restrictions.
notes_C4: Requirements for social distancing are in place, but from the Smart Restart Tiered Capacity guidance dated January 20th, 2021, it does not appear that any restrictions on numbers are enforced, just differential guidance for differently-sized events  Smart Restart Plan Gatherings & Events Guidance: https://web.archive.org/web/20210313122409/https://ndresponse.gov/sites/www/files/documents/covid-19/ND%20Smart%20Restart/NDSmartRestart-LargeGatheringTieredCapacityDoc.pdf
notes_C5: As of 13th March 2021, mass transit operators appear to be referred by the North Dakota State Government only to general CDC guidance  ND State Government Guidance: https://web.archive.org/web/20210313121440/https://ndresponse.gov/covid-19-resources/covid-19-business-and-employer-resources/nd-smart-restart/nd-smart-restart-protocols
notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: As of April 27th, the eviction moratorium is still in place.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210424154911/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf
notes_H1: North Dakota Department of Health continues to share information regarding COVID-19 cases, testing and vaccines on its media platforms    https://archive.vn/k2trc

notes_H3: Though the COVID-19 state of emergency in North Dakota ends on April 30, the North Dakota Department of Health "will continue to conduct case investigation and contact tracing".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503065003/https://www.health.nd.gov/news/north-dakota-department-health-continues-public-health-recommendations-after-emergency
notes_H6: As of April 27th, the mask mandate for federal buildings and recommendations for mask-wearing on public transportation still stand.     The CDC updated its mask-wearing guidance on April 27th for those who have been fully vaccinated, stating:   "You can gather indoors with fully vaccinated people without wearing a mask or staying 6 feet apart." notes_H7: Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson    North Dakota Governor and Saskatchewan Premier signed a "Memorandum of Understanding to vaccinate essential workers who are transporting goods across the United States and Canadian border".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503062718/https://www.health.nd.gov/news/joint-release-north-dakota-and-saskatchewan-sign-agreement-vaccinate-essential-workers

name: Nebraska
notes_C1: As of March 28, all counties in Nebraska are still in the Green Zone, so schools should be open. Many schools in major cities have moved to in-person learning.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322114236/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/DHM-Measure-Table-ENGLISH.pdf https://web.archive.org/web/20210329152716/https://district.ops.org/DEPARTMENTS/General-Finance-and-Administrative-Services/District-Communications/In-Person-Learning https://web.archive.org/web/20210329153214/https://www.1011now.com/2021/01/22/lps-seniors-can-return-to-full-in-person-learning-next-month/
notes_C2: As of April 27th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426140506/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426042602/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html

notes_C4: As of March 28, all counties in Nebraska are still in the Green Zone. There are no gathering restrictions. Venues with the capacity to host 500 or more people are required to submit plans to local health departments to be approved in advance.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322114236/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/DHM-Measure-Table-ENGLISH.pdf
notes_C5: no policy change.
notes_C6: As of March 28, the Nebraska Department of Health & Human Services continues to recommend staying at home and working from home, except for essential activities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329153531/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Protect-Yourself-and-Others.aspx
notes_C7: On April 21, Nebraska will update its guidance in relation to travel, both domestic and internationally.  The CDC recommends the following:    For unvaccinated travelers:  Recommended: get tested 1-3 days prior to travel out of the U.S.  Required: testing within 3 days prior to return to US via airline or documentation of recovery  ?Recommended: testing 3-5 days after return to U.S. AND quarantine 7 days after travel, or quarantine 10 days if no testing  ?For fully vaccinated travelers:  ?Required: testing within 3 days prior to return to U.S. via airline or documentation of recovery  Recommended: testing 3-5 days after return to U.S. but no need to quarantine  Visit https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html  for more information    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503123312/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-COVID-19-Weekly-Update-04212021.aspx
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On April 6th, the governor of Nebraska discussed about rental assistance.    We want to remind landlords and tenants about the Emergency Rental Assistance Program available to help with rent and utilities for eligible tenants who are struggling with rent or utility payments due to COVID-19 related financial hardship.  When the State kicked off its program on February 22nd, we noted that Lancaster County, Douglas County, Lincoln, and Omaha were all covered under separate programs, which had not yet launched.  As of today, we are pleased to announce that the City of Lincoln and Lancaster County programs are live.  The City of Omaha’s emergency rental assistance program is also live as of today, April 5th.  The Douglas County program is planning to launch sometime during mid-April.  The links to these programs can be found at coronavirus.nebraska.gov/EmergencyRentalAssistanceProgram.   Applicants living outside of Lancaster and Douglas counties should apply through the State’s website at coronavirus.nebraska.gov.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210408155738/https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-urges-nebraskans-get-their-coronavirus-vaccination
notes_E2: The CDC eviction moratorium and the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) are still in place (until March 31).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322114912/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Energy-Assistance.aspx
notes_H1: On April 28, DHHS continues to share new information via the Coronavirus website, as well as Facebook and Twitter and at virtual town halls. Each week, members of the DHHS team hold a mid-day Facebook Live session to discuss vaccine-related and pandemic-related topics. For those unable to watch live, all sessions are archived and available on the video tab of the DHHS Facebook page  and the DHHS website.    This week, DHHS Chief Executive Officer Dannette Smith and Dr. Emily Patel, a maternal and fetal medicine specialist at Nebraska Methodist Hospital, will discuss COVID-19 vaccines and Women's Health Month at noon on Thursday, April 29.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503131805/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-COVID-19-Weekly-Update-04282021.aspx
notes_H2: On April 28, testing continues to be available to help limit the spread of COVID-19.  Anyone who may have been exposed to COVID-19, anyone experiencing any symptoms, those planning to travel, or those returning from travel are encouraged to schedule a COVID-19 test.  Free testing is available at more than 60 Test Nebraska sites across the state, and has remained steady; rapid tests may be available for a fee at some medical walk-in centers.  As of today, over 2,828,074 tests have been administered throughout Nebraska.    COVID-19 symptoms can include fever or chills, cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, tiredness, muscle aches, headache, loss of taste or smell, sore throat, runny nose, nausea or vomiting, and diarrhea.  Those infected with any variant will show these same symptoms. The severity of a B.1.1.7 variant infection appears to be elevated compared to normal strains, based on international hospitalization and mortality data.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210503131805/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-COVID-19-Weekly-Update-04282021.aspx
notes_H3: On April 12,he Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) and Nebraska Public Health Lab (NPHL) have confirmed that the New York variant of COVID-19, known as B1.526 has arrived in the state. The initial case has been identified as a Douglas County resident. An investigation is underway and ongoing. The identified B1.526 variant has been spreading throughout the United States, specifically in the Northeast, and is still being studied to determine the level of contagiousness and severity. Testing platforms like Test Nebraska and others will still produce a “positive” result for the identified B1.526 variant (and other variants). It is expected that vaccinations will remain effective.      Nebraska’s Chief Medical Officer Dr. Gary Anthone said, “We have continued to stress that Nebraskans cannot let up on our mitigation efforts and testing remains critical against not only the spread, but preventing another major surge of COVID-19 cases. As these variants continue to be discovered in the state, vaccinations, testing, masking, and distancing remain the best defenses we have in this fight. I strongly encourage that individuals continue to get tested, especially if they have symptoms and have not yet been vaccinated.”    As researchers learn more about this and other variants it remains as important as ever to continue masking, distancing, and avoiding the 3Cs. Get a test if you’re exposed or if you develop symptoms. Register now at vaccinate.ne.gov and get the vaccine when it’s offered to you to help Nebraska FinishStrong.      DHHS and NPHL have been working to increase sequencing capabilities within the state. Higher volumes of in-state sequencing began in January and NPHL currently has capacity to sequence more than 100 specimens per week. Creighton University is also sequencing roughly 100 specimens per week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210413031943/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Nebraska-Identifies-B1-526-Variant-of-COVID-19.aspx
notes_H6: As of April 27th, the mask mandate for federal buildings and recommendations for mask-wearing on public transportation still stand.     The CDC updated its mask-wearing guidance on April 27th for those who have been fully vaccinated, stating:   "You can gather indoors with fully vaccinated people without wearing a mask or staying 6 feet apart."    See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427062253/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html  See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427035558/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/using-transportation.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426161816/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2021/01/20/executive-order-protecting-the-federal-workforce-and-requiring-mask-wearing/
notes_H7: On April 26, the Nebraska Department of Health and Human Services has announced the resumption of offering the Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine. Appropriate providers should resume administering doses of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, according to state officials.      Nebraska is following Friday's recommendations of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in lifting the pause. The two federal agencies had earlier recommended a pause in using Johnson & Johnson doses.      The safety and effectiveness of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine has been confirmed by the CDC and the FDA. Nebraska providers who have a current supply of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine should resume using those doses, according to state officials.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210503130440/https://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Nebraska-Resumes-Johnson-and-Johnson-Vaccines.aspx

name: New Jersey
notes_C1: The majority of schools are open in some form for in-person learning; however, the state website says, "School closure is a local decision that should be made by school administrators in consultation with local public health officials." Schools must follow the reopening health/safety guidance issued by the state.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503111616/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/reopening-guidance-and-restrictions/are-schools-open-what-are-the-safety-requirements
notes_C2: The New Jersey government has comprehensive guidance on business reopening on their website, including employers' responsibilities to their employees and the health and safety guidance that must be followed if businesses want to be open.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503113549/https://business.nj.gov/covid
notes_C3: Public events are allowed to take place in accordance with state guidelines on gathering limits and reopening guidance.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503113941/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/reopening-guidance-and-restrictions/how-can-people-safely-get-together-what-are-the-limits-for-indoor-and-outdoor-gatherings     Rachelle Koch (Reviewer) Edit:    Code changed to 1G (from 1T) because policy applies to the entire state.
notes_C4: General indoor gatherings are limited to 25 people, and general outdoor gatherings are limited to 200 people with social distancing. More specific rules available at the archived source below.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503113941/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/reopening-guidance-and-restrictions/how-can-people-safely-get-together-what-are-the-limits-for-indoor-and-outdoor-gatherings
notes_C5: Public transport mostly running at full capacity, but enhanced cleaning regimes are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503114302/https://www.njtransit.com/covid19
notes_C6: Symptomatic individuals should self-isolate and stay home; nothing specific recommending asymptomatic individuals to stay home.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503114642/https://covid19.nj.gov/
notes_C7: Unvaccinated individuals are strongly discouraged from non-essential interstate travel at this time. Unvaccinated travelers and residents returning from any U.S. state or territory beyond the immediate region should self-quarantine and/or get tested. You no longer need to quarantine or get tested before/after domestic travel if you are fully vaccinated or have clinically recovered from COVID-19 in the past three months.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503115210/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/travel-and-transportation/are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: There are narrow protections for New Jersey workers, such as Work First New Jersey (WFNJ), which includes Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) and General Assistance (GA), which provides monthly cash. There are also unemployment benefits and emergency paid sick/childcare leave available for application.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503120003/https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/assistance-and-benefits/what-types-of-benefits-or-assistance-are-available-to-me-during-the-coronavirus-outbreak
notes_E2: New Jerseyans are protected from eviction, and if affected by COVID-19, residents can apply to request mortgage payment forbearance for up to 90 days. notes_H6: Face coverings are required in all outdoor public spaces when social distancing is not possible, and in indoor public spaces. notes_C2: Several counties are in the "yellow" tier, the second-highest level; none remain in the "red" tier. Businesses have capacity restrictions, with bars and clubs closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501173605/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501173608/https://cvprovider.nmhealth.org/public-dashboard.html
notes_C3: Several counties are in the "yellow" tier, the second-highest level; none remain in the "red" tier. Outdoor events are permitted, but not indoor ones.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501173605/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501173608/https://cvprovider.nmhealth.org/public-dashboard.html
notes_C4: Several counties are in the "yellow" tier, the second-highest level; none remain in the "red" tier. Gatherings of up to 10 people are permitted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501173605/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501173608/https://cvprovider.nmhealth.org/public-dashboard.html
notes_C5: All transit operators in the state appear to have resumed service. A few individual bus routes and stops have been suspended.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501173854/https://www.riometro.org/CivicAlerts.aspx?AID=237
notes_C6: Citizens are advised to stay at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501173949/https://cv.nmhealth.org/covid-safe-practices/
notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: Eviction moratorium extended through June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210424145832/https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/ban-renter-evictions-covid-19-pandemic-extended-76747843
notes_H1: Public campaign continues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501173605/https://cv.nmhealth.org/public-health-orders-and-executive-orders/red-to-green/
notes_H2: Testing is widely available without restrictions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501174430/https://cvprovider.nmhealth.org/directory.html
notes_H3: No policy change.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501174601/https://cvmodeling.nmhealth.org/public-health-gating-criteria-for-reopening-nm/contact-tracing-and-isolation-capacity/

As an example of the events that are currently occuring in Ohio, exerpt from Lakewood, Ohio's website: "After reviewing the most recent guidance and recommendations from the CDC and the Ohio Department of Health, the city is pleased to announce that there will be some summer events held this year.  However, the larger events, where social distancing is not feasible, unfortunately, will not take place. Below is a list of events and details of modification or cancelation, where applicable:    Meet the Trucks – Meet the Trucks will not be held the first Saturday in June due to the required social distancing guidelines.  But LECPTA and the city are considering a fall date if the event can be done safely.    Summer Solstice – The Summer Solstice Celebration will not be held this year due to the large crowds this event draws making required social distancing difficult.    Independence Day – Fireworks are planned. No parade or concert will be held this year due to required social distancing guidelines.    Friday Night Flicks – Five movies will be shown this summer using social distancing circles. More information on dates and movies to be shown will be announced soon.    Concerts in the Park – No summer concerts will be scheduled. Unfortunately, ensuring required social distancing during these events is not possible."    Link to press release site on April 25:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210426030029/https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/covid-19/resources/news-releases-news-you-can-use    Link to Lakewood, Ohio's Summer Events site:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210426030626/http://www.onelakewood.com/2021-summer-events-update/

name: Oklahoma
notes_C1: OKCPS still uses the existing A/B schedule for all students. All students in grades PK-12th will Return to Campus for in-person learning 4 days a week, Tuesday - Friday. Mondays will remain a remote learning day for all students. All students currently enrolled in the Online Learning program will continue to learn virtually for the remainder of the school year.     Broken Arrow Public Schools is currently in the YELLOW PHASE meaning Social distancing practiced as much as possible, Large group activities-school-wide assemblies may be allowed with students and teacher only, masks are required indoors for 3rd-12th grade students and are highly recommended for Pre-K-2nd grade students.    The OU Norman Campus is currently in Phase III of its return plan (which began on Monday, Aug. 3, 2020) meaning access to campus buildings returned to normal operations, all common areas are maintained in a manner that provides for social distancing and safe hygiene practices, all individuals inside University facilities and vehicles must wear masks.    OKCPS link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503032855/https://www.okcps.org/domain/1846    Broken Arrow Public Schools Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503034057/https://www.baschools.org/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503034215/https://www.baschools.org/vnews/display.v/ART/5f3c22c9f1666    OU Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210416145314/https://ou.edu/together/norman-phase-iii
notes_C2: Businesses must follow the Open Up & Recover Safely (OURS) Plan stating that All businesses and organizations should follow general CDC guidelines. Businesses are allowed to remain open but Employees and visitors are required to follow sanitation, hygiene and social distancing guidelines.    OK Commerce Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503023141/https://www.okcommerce.gov/covid19/ours-plan/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210425043142/https://www.okcommerce.gov/wp-content/uploads/Open-Up-and-Recover-Safely-Plan.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503023244/https://www.okcommerce.gov/covid19/open-up-recover-safely-ours-plan-faqs/
notes_C3: On March 12, 2021 Gov. Kevin Stitt announced he will issue a new executive order eliminating limits on public gatherings and attendance limits at indoor sporting events. No further large changes were made since then. No new executive order was found.     Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503031339if_/https://www.oklahoman.com/story/news/2021/03/11/oklahoma-gov-kevin-stitt-undo-remaining-covid-19-restrictions/6947773002/
notes_C4: On March 12, 2021 Gov. Kevin Stitt announced he will issue a new executive order eliminating limits on public gatherings and attendance limits at indoor sporting events.
