notes_C5: Face masks are required on all Tulsa transit vehicles, at stations, sub-hubs and bus stops. Masks must cover both the mouth and nose. “Recommended masks are medical procedure masks (disposable) and properly worn breathable masks, with 2+ layers.” “The Order defines a mask as material covering the wearer’s nose and mouth and excludes: face shields, scarves, goggles, ski masks, balaclavas, bandanas and shirts pulled over the face.”    “The City of Tulsa’s face mask ordinance will expire on April 30th. However, riders will still need to comply with the federal mask mandate.”    Link:  https://archive.vn/rDvIB
notes_C6: As of April 26, 2021, the COVID-19 alert system report shows that many counties are now yellow (1.43 to 14.29 cases per 100 000) , 17 are green (less than 1.43 cases per 100 000) and 1 remain orange (more than 14.29 cases per 100 000). General guidelines for individuals include staying home if feeling sick. General guidelines for high-risk individuals include using appropriate precautions and avoiding high-risk areas for any travel.    Link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210503051902/https://oklahoma.gov/content/dam/ok/en/covid19/documents/alert-system/risk-level-trends/County%20Risk%20Levels%2020210427.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427014949/https://oklahoma.gov/content/dam/ok/en/covid19/documents/alert-system/oklahomas_low_phase_flyer_english.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427014945/https://oklahoma.gov/content/dam/ok/en/covid19/documents/alert-system/oklahomas_new_normal_phase_flyer_english.pdf
notes_C7: “With the “Safer in Oklahoma” policy, individuals entering the State of Oklahoma from an area with substantial community spread, will wear a face covering in all public spaces and limit participating indoor gatherings for 10-14 days in accordance with CDC guidelines.”  “Public health officials recommend you stay home as much as possible, especially if your trip is not essential, and practice social distancing especially if you are at higher risk of severe illness. Don’t travel if you are sick or travel with someone who is sick. Public health officials recommend older adults and those with chronic health conditions consider postponing travel.”    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503053437/https://oklahoma.gov/covid19/resources-recommendations/travel.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427073049/https://oklahoma.gov/content/dam/ok/en/covid19/images/fb-travel-prevention-eng.pdf
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: “Restore Hope Ministries has been selected by the City of Tulsa and Tulsa County as the lead agency to administer $19.6 million in critical federal funding to provide much needed rent and utility relief to Tulsa City and County residents”. The program helps landlords and tenants by paying past due rent, utilities (water, gas, and electric) and, in some cases, forward rent for up to three months to ensure housing stability.    People who are eligible are Tulsa residents over the age of 18, household income at or below 80 percent Area Media Income, experiencing difficulty with housing and esperience a reduction in household income, incurred significant costs, experienced a financial hardship due to COVID-19, or have qualified for unemployment benefits since March 13, 2020.    The application extends through Dec. 31, 2021 (or until allocated funding is exhausted)    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503062358/https://www.cityoftulsa.org/press-room/applications-open-for-second-round-of-emergency-rental-assistance-program-in-tulsa-county/
notes_E2: The moratorium on evictions implemented to protect renters in danger of becoming unhoused during the COVID-19 pandemic has been extended through the end of June.     "The moratorium that was scheduled to expire on March 31, 2021 is now extended through June 30, 2021."    Link: https://archive.vn/qziss
notes_H1: Chief of government affairs for the Oklahoma City-County Health Department releases statement addressing the need to increase the number of younger people getting the vaccine. "We really need those individuals who are 18 to 35, 18 to 40 even, to understand the importance of getting the vaccine.”    The Oklahoma Department of Health continues to encourage residents to get vaccinated through their Twitter.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503064630/https://www.koco.com/article/okc-county-health-department-makes-push-to-get-young-people-vaccinated/36307409    https://archive.vn/x7tdk
notes_H2: COVID.19 tests are widely available by appointment. OCCHD will schedule appointments for anyone wanting to be tested. People will not be tested without an appointment. The drive thru COVID-19 testing locations can be found online.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426161044/https://www.occhd.org/okctestsites    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503070419/https://oklahoma.gov/covid19/testing-sites.html
notes_H3: As of May 3, 2021, “There are approximately 700 trained contact tracers currently working active cases in Oklahoma.”    Contact traicing in Oklahoma involves: “Interviewing people with COVID-19 to identify everyone they had close contact with during the time they may have been infectious, notifying contacts of their potential exposure, referring contacts for testing, monitoring contacts for signs and symptoms of COVID-19 and connecting contacts with services they might need during the self-quarantine period”    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503212630/https://oklahoma.gov/covid19/resources-recommendations/contact-tracing-0.html
notes_H6: “Starting May 1, the City of Tulsa’s mask mandate will no longer be in effect. When the mandate expires, it will end the requirement for masks in places of public accommodation, the spacing requirements for restaurants and bars, and the mask requirement for restaurant and bar employees. Any business or venue may still choose to require masks at their establishment. Those visiting any public-facing City facilities are required to wear a mask until further notice. This requirement also remains in place for all City employees.”    Places to shop and gather in Oklahoma City may still require masks even after the mask ordinance expired on April 30.    Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503220757/https://www.cityoftulsa.org/covid-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503221106/https://www.cityoftulsa.org/mask    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503220405/https://www.okc.gov/Home/Components/News/News/3833/5296
notes_H7: Vaccine appointments are available for all adults aged 16 and older, living in any state. Oklahoma residency is no longer required.     “Anyone living in Oklahoma or any other state, aged 16 and older, is now eligible for vaccine appointments.  Phases 1-4 of the vaccine distribution plan are now open. Pfizer is the only vaccine currently approved for minors aged 16 or 17 years.”    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503221835/https://vaccinate.oklahoma.gov/en-US/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503222253/https://kfor.com/news/local/watch-oklahoma-state-department-of-health-vaccine-rollout-update/

name: Oregon
notes_C1: No apparent change in policy
notes_C2: On April 30th 2021, Governor Brown moved 15 counties of Oregon's 36, comprising some 70% of Oregon's population into the 'extreme' risk level. 8 counties remain at 'lower' risk level', 4 at 'moderate' and 9 at 'high'. At 'extreme' risk level, offices are required to require home working if possible, and restraunts can offer outdoor service and takeaway only. Indoor entertainment venues of >500sq ft are limited to 6 people or fewer with 25ft social distancing between households and an 11PM curfew - which, unless the economics of entertainment are vastly different in the States, strikes me as a de facto closing order.    Guidance for all risk levels: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502181844/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/guidance.aspx  Oregon Live on the new restrictions: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502183129/https://www.oregonlive.com/news/2021/04/governor-says-extreme-risk-covid-19-restrictions-will-save-hundreds-in-oregon-i-chose-to-save-lives.html // https://web.archive.org/web/20210502183220/https://www.oregonlive.com/news/2021/04/these-15-oregon-counties-will-move-to-extreme-risk-covid-19-restrictions-according-to-the-governors-office.html  Current county risk levels: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502183323/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/living-with-covid-19.aspx  Governor's press release April 30th: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502001830/https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=54639  Governor's press release April 29th, on extension of the state of emergency: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502183702/https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=54627
notes_C3: On April 30th 2021, Governor Brown moved 15 counties of Oregon's 36, comprising some 70% of Oregon's population into the 'extreme' risk level. 8 counties remain at 'lower' risk level', 4 at 'moderate' and 9 at 'high'. At 'extreme' risk level, gatherings are limited to 6 people in- or outdoors, and outdoor entertainment and recreation is limited to 100 people with an 11PM curfew    Guidance for all risk levels: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502181844/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/guidance.aspx  Oregon Live on the new restrictions: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502183129/https://www.oregonlive.com/news/2021/04/governor-says-extreme-risk-covid-19-restrictions-will-save-hundreds-in-oregon-i-chose-to-save-lives.html // https://web.archive.org/web/20210502183220/https://www.oregonlive.com/news/2021/04/these-15-oregon-counties-will-move-to-extreme-risk-covid-19-restrictions-according-to-the-governors-office.html  Current county risk levels: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502183323/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/living-with-covid-19.aspx  Governor's press release April 30th: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502001830/https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=54639  Governor's press release April 29th, on extension of the state of emergency: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502183702/https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=54627
notes_C4: On April 30th 2021, Governor Brown moved 15 counties of Oregon's 36, comprising some 70% of Oregon's population into the 'extreme' risk level. 8 counties remain at 'lower' risk level', 4 at 'moderate' and 9 at 'high'. At 'extreme' risk level, gatherings are limited to 6 people in- or outdoors, and outdoor entertainment and recreation is limited to 100 people with an 11PM curfew    Guidance for all risk levels: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502181844/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/guidance.aspx  Oregon Live on the new restrictions: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502183129/https://www.oregonlive.com/news/2021/04/governor-says-extreme-risk-covid-19-restrictions-will-save-hundreds-in-oregon-i-chose-to-save-lives.html // https://web.archive.org/web/20210502183220/https://www.oregonlive.com/news/2021/04/these-15-oregon-counties-will-move-to-extreme-risk-covid-19-restrictions-according-to-the-governors-office.html  Current county risk levels: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502183323/https://coronavirus.oregon.gov/Pages/living-with-covid-19.aspx  Governor's press release April 30th: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502001830/https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=54639  Governor's press release April 29th, on extension of the state of emergency: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502183702/https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=54627
notes_C5: Transit agencies are required to implement masks and 3-foot social distancing  Transit Agency guidance: https://web.archive.org/web/20210418152459/https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le2355.pdf
notes_C6: Staying at home and avoiding non-essential travel is reccommended, but not required.    Statewide travel guidance: https://web.archive.org/web/20210418153835/https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le2351r.pdf
notes_C7: Staying at home and avoiding non-essential travel is reccommended, but not required.    Statewide travel guidance: https://web.archive.org/web/20210418153835/https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le2351r.pdf
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: The following policy remains in effect:  PUA provides unemployment benefits to workers who have never before been eligible for benefits. To qualify, you must be:  Out of work due to COVID-19, and  Not eligible for any other unemployment benefits. This includes:  Self-employed people  Independent contractors  Some gig workers (gig workers whose employers are not required to pay payroll taxes on their wages)  Employees whose wages are not reported for unemployment insurance, like some agricultural workers  Employees who have not earned enough wages or worked enough hours for regular unemployment benefits  Employees who ran out of regular unemployment benefits, and are not eligible for another extension  People who were going to start work but could not, due to a COVID-19 situation  The minimum PUA benefit is $205 per week. You will get at least that much if you are eligible. The maximum is $648 per week. Your weekly benefit amount is 1.25 percent of your earnings over the last 12 months. It is net earnings (earnings minus expenses) for self-employed workers, but gross earnings (total earnings) for other workers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210331213858/https://unemployment.oregon.gov/frequently-asked-questions#faqTopic-2008
notes_E2: No new announcements
notes_H1: Information resources designed for public use by Oregon's Health Authority can be viewed here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210418160746/https://govstatus.egov.com/or-oha-covid-resources
notes_H2: State testing page: https://web.archive.org/web/20210430200647/https://govstatus.egov.com/or-oha-covid-19-testing  Testing FAQs: https://web.archive.org/web/20210418161122/https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3574.pdf
notes_H3: During the week of the 4th April 2021 only 36.2% of cases were tracked to a known source, well below the OHA's own target of 70%    Oregon Public Health contact tracing response: https://web.archive.org/web/20210418161550/https://public.tableau.com/profile/oregon.health.authority.covid.19
notes_H6: The upgrading of the 15 counties to extreme risk does not appear to affect mask policy, which is detailed here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210501113106/https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le2288k.pdf   See previous notes for further details.
notes_H7: All Oregonians over 16 continue to be eligible to recieve vaccination.  State vaccine page: https://web.archive.org/web/20210501112848/https://covidvaccine.oregon.gov/

name: Pennsylvania
notes_C1: No change.    "For Phase III, students in the following groups will be able to opt into the hybrid learning model, beginning the week of Monday, May 10, 2021:    all students in grades 6-9 who have not yet returned, and  students with complex needs in grades 10-12."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501215743/https://www.philasd.org/coronavirus/schoolstart2020/
notes_C2: No change in code.    In PA:  "Child care safety guidance in place  Congregate care restrictions in place  Prison and hospital restrictions determined by individual facilities  Schools subject to CDC and commonwealth guidance  Telework is strongly encouraged  Businesses with in-person operations must follow updated business and building safety requirements  Face coverings are required in businesses  All in-person businesses may operate at 75% occupancy  Indoor dining at restaurants open at 50% (75% for self-certified restaurants)"    In Philadelphia:  "Indoor events are limited to 15% of a venue's capacity, while outdoor events are allowed at 20% capacity.    Indoor dining is allowed at 25% of an eatery's capacity. A restaurant can increase capacity to 50% if it meets enhanced ventilation criteria and completes the required application.    Outdoor dining is allowed with a 50-person limit. However, businesses that want to go above the 50-person threshold can submit an application to the Department of Licenses and Inspections. "    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501223253/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501223426/https://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/coronavirus/what-the-updated-covid-restrictions-in-pa-nj-and-del-mean-for-you/2795340/
notes_C3: No change in code.    In PA:  "Gathering limits in place:  Indoor events: 25% of maximum occupancy, regardless of venue size and only if attendees and workers are able to comply with the 6-foot physical distancing requirement  Outdoor events: 50% of maximum occupancy, regardless of venue size and only if attendees and workers are able to comply with the 6-foot physical distancing requirement"    In Philadelphia:  "Indoor events are limited to 15% of a venue's capacity, while outdoor events are allowed at 20% capacity."    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501223253/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501223426/https://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/coronavirus/what-the-updated-covid-restrictions-in-pa-nj-and-del-mean-for-you/2795340/
notes_C4: No change in code.    "Gathering limits in place:  Indoor events: 25% of maximum occupancy, regardless of venue size and only if attendees and workers are able to comply with the 6-foot physical distancing requirement  Outdoor events: 50% of maximum occupancy, regardless of venue size and only if attendees and workers are able to comply with the 6-foot physical distancing requirement"    In Philadelphia:  "Indoor events are limited to 15% of a venue's capacity, while outdoor events are allowed at 20% capacity."    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501223253/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501223426/https://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/coronavirus/what-the-updated-covid-restrictions-in-pa-nj-and-del-mean-for-you/2795340/
notes_C5: No change in code.    "All SEPTA passengers are required to wear a face mask or covering. Regular service schedules are in effect. The 12th & Filbert doors at Jefferson Station are open 7 days a week from 6:30 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. The 16th & JFK doors at Suburban Station will be open during the following hours: 6:30 a.m. to 9:30 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. (Monday-Friday only). During all other hours these doors will be locked."    Source:  https://archive.vn/0OgEn
notes_C6: No mention of stay at home advisories/requirements on state's "Responding to Covid-19" website.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501223253/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/
notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: No change on unemployment benefits websites.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501224617/https://www.uc.pa.gov/unemployment-benefits/file/Pages/Filing-for-PUA.aspx    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501225042/https://www.uc.pa.gov/COVID-19/Pages/default.aspx
notes_E2: No change in code. Moratoriums on evictions and foreclosures are federal.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501225304/https://www.uwp.org/pacovid/
notes_H1: No change in code. Campaigns appear up to date.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501223253/https://www.pa.gov/guides/responding-to-covid-19/
notes_H2: No change.    "No appointment is necessary. Testing is on a first-come, first-serve basis and is completely free to all patients. Patients must be ages three and older and are not required to show symptoms of COVID-19 in order to be tested. Up to 450 patients can be tested per day. Mid-nasal passage swab PCR tests will be performed. Patients are encouraged to bring a photo-ID or insurance card. Registration will also be completed on-site. The turnaround time for testing results is two to seven days after testing."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501225701/https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Public%20Testing.aspx
notes_H3: No change.    "If you test positive, a public health staff member will try to call you within 24 to 48 hours of receiving the test result. They will conduct a case investigation or share a Connect & Protect Form and collect the people and places you come in contact with while you were infectious. While you isolate for a minimum of ten days, contact tracers will reach out to your close contacts to inform them that they were exposed, educate them on what to do and provide supports and testing information as necessary for the situation. Contact tracers will not use your name when reaching out to your close contacts. Your information will stay confidential."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501230342/https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Contact-Tracing.aspx
notes_H6: General requirements for mask wearing:  "The Order requires individuals to wear a face covering when indoors, irrespective of physical distance. When outdoors, one must wear a face covering when with others who are not members of the person's household and unable to maintain sustained physical distance."    PA has adopted the same guidelines for mask wearing as those that were published by the CDC on April 27, 2021. The "CDC announcement allows those who are fully vaccinated the opportunity to spend time outdoors, in some situations, without wearing a mask." Because most individuals in PA are not fully vaccinated yet, the policy is coded as a 3G to capture the dominant tendency.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501231155/https://www.media.pa.gov/Pages/Health-Details.aspx?newsid=1425    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501231440/https://www.health.pa.gov/topics/disease/coronavirus/Pages/Guidance/Universal-Masking-FAQ.aspx    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501231651/https://www.yourerie.com/health/coronavirus/pennsylvania-department-of-health-releases-covid-19-update-for-may-1st/
notes_H7: A,B,C:    All Pennsylvanians over 16 are eligible to receive a vaccine.    Moderna, Pfizer, and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are being administered. Pause of Johnson & Johnson vaccine administration was lifted on April 23, 2021 in both PA and Philadelphia.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210501232124/https://www.media.pa.gov/pages/health-details.aspx?newsid=1419    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501232246/https://www.phillyvoice.com/johnson-johnson-covid-19-vaccine-philadelphia-pennsylvania-new-jersey/

name: Rhode Island
notes_C1: As of 18 April 2021, schools in Rhode Island are open for in-person or blended learning. Face coverings are required for all staff and K-12 students, at all times, even in stable group settings, and even when socially distanced.    No evidence found to suggest that in-person learning does not continue to some extent at University of Rhode Island.    Back2School RI website:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210418143550/https://www.back2schoolri.com/    RI schools guidance:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210418143627/https://www.ride.ri.gov/Portals/0/Uploads/Documents/COVID19/HealthandSafetyReopeningGuidance.pdf?ver=2021-03-10-110839-843    URI latest update:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210418143658/https://web.uri.edu/coronavirus/2021/03/12/vaccination-covid-19-updates/
notes_C2: As of 16 April 2021, EO 21-29 remains in effect.     - Outdoor dining is encouraged but outdoor seating is limited to a capacity of 10 people.   - People should work remotely if possible.   - Nightclubs must remain closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418141427/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-27.pdf
notes_C3: In EO 21-34, Governor Daniel McKee ordered that effective 9 April 2021:    - Venues of assembly, including convention centers, concert halls, performance venues, spectator sporting event venues and theaters may operate up to 50% capacity with a cap of 250 people indoors and 500 people outdoors. This is permitted up until 14 May 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418140107/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-34.pdf
notes_C4: In EO 21-34, Governor Daniel McKee ordered that effective 9 April 2021:    - Indoor public and private social gatherings are limited to 15 people  - Outdoor public and private social gatherings are limited to 50 people    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418140107/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-34.pdf
notes_C5: As of 18 April 2021, no evidence has been found for amendments to public transportation services in Rhode Island.     Rhode Island Public Transit Authority states that face masks are required to be worn at all times and social distancing should be observed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418142121/https://www.ripta.com/covid-19/
notes_C6: As of 16 April 2021, EO 21-27 remains in effect, vulnerable people are encouraged to stay at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418141427/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-27.pdf
notes_C7: As of 16 April 2021, EO 21-27 remains in effect. People who have travelled outside Rhode Island and the US must self-quarantine for 10 days. Exemptions apply. This order is effective until April 17th.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418141427/https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-21-27.pdf
notes_C8: As of April 6th, international travel controls are in place. Foreign nationals from many countries/regions are disallowed from entering the United States. US nationals and other eligible individuals must show proof of a negative COVID test within 72 hours of departing for the US. Quarantine and testing recommendations are in place.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405213532/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405214749/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: As of 18 April 2021, those who have been laid off due to the pandemic may be eligible for the state's unemployment insurance. If individuals are self-employed or a contract worker, they must apply for Pandemic Unemployment Assistance.    It is unclear whether this support provides <50% or >50% of the lost income. Coding as 1F, however this may not reflect the situation on the ground.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418135125/https://dlt.ri.gov/ui/faq/
notes_E2: As of 18 April 2021, the winter moratorium on utilities remains in effect. This will expire on 25 June 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418104730/https://www.providenceri.gov/pema/covid-19-housing-resource-guide/
notes_H1: As of 14 March 2021, Rhode Island's Department of Health continues to provide information pertaining to the COVID-19 response within the state via the RIDOH COVID-19 website.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418102750/https://covid.ri.gov/
notes_H2: As of 18 April 2021, there is no detected change in Rhode Island's testing policy.    Testing is currently widely available for those who are both symptomatic and asymptomatic.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210418103341/https://covid.ri.gov/testing
notes_H3: As of 18 April 2021, no evidence has been identified to suggest a deviation away from comprehensive contact tracing in Rhode Island.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210418103245/https://covid.ri.gov/covid-19-prevention/contact-tracing
notes_H6: As of 18 April 2021, EO 20-30 remains in effect. Face masks are still required to be worn are still required in all public spaces, whether indoors or outdoors, unless a mask exception applies. name: South Carolina
notes_C1: Schools recommended to follow CDC guidelines surrounding implementation of strategies that align with local level of transmission https://web.archive.org/web/20210502233817/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/resources-community-covid-19/schools-childcare-centers-covid-19
notes_C2: As of April 27th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426140506/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426042602/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html
notes_C3: Enacted 08 March 2021, Executive Order No. 2021-13 extends Executive Order No. 2021-12 (enacted 05 March 2021) for 15 days, until 22 March 2021. Executive Order No. 2021-12 modifies and renews emergency measures for COVID-19.    Executive Order No. 2021-12 recommends that businesses, facilities, events, and other mass gatherings do not exceed 250 people or 50% of a facility's occupancy limit, whichever comes first (see Section 4 Paragraph B).  This is a change from Executive Order No. 2020-73, which prohibited gatherings of this size.     According to Executive Order No. 2021-12, a gathering does not include military, healthcare, public safety, emergency response, or the United States CISA operations. It also does not include schools and higher education institutions or religious activities or services and the facilities in which they occur (see Section 4 Paragraph C).     Residents of South Carolina partaking in gatherings are still encouraged to practice social distancing (in accordance with the CDC, DHEC, etc).    Link to Executive Order No. 2021-13 (searchable text):  https://archive.ph/yP0G4  Link to Executive Order No. 2021-12 (searchable text):  https://archive.vn/AaAlg
notes_C4: The latest updated Executive Order from the Governor of the state includes no mention of restrictions on gatherings (previous orders included specific passaged on emergency restrictions on gatherings).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210421112834/https://governor.sc.gov/sites/default/files/Documents/Images/2021-04-07%20FINAL%20Executive%20Order%20No.%202021-18%20-%20State%20of%20Emergency.pdf
notes_C5: Enacted 08 March 2021, Executive Order No. 2021-13 extends Executive Order No. 2021-12 (enacted 05 March 2021) for 15 days, until 22 March 2021. Executive Order No. 2021-12 modifies and renews emergency measures for COVID-19.    There are no statewide restrictions on public transportation.     Link to Executive Order No. 2021-13 (searchable text):  https://archive.ph/yP0G4  Link to Executive Order No. 2021-12 (searchable text):  https://archive.vn/AaAlg
notes_C6: Original note from Rachelle Koch: As of 29 March 2021, although the CDC provides guidelines on what to consider when deciding to go out, it does not explicitly recommend staying at home. The website encourages the following:    Wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth to help protect yourself and others.  Stay 6 feet apart from others who don’t live with you.  Get a COVID-19 vaccine when it is available to you.  Avoid crowds and poorly ventilated indoor spaces.  Wash your hands often with soap and water. Use hand sanitizer if soap and water aren’t available.    Link to CDC "Protect Yourself" webpage:  https://archive.vn/nC2Yn    Additional note from Reviewer Monika Pyarali: coding updated from 0 to 1G due to further evidence of continued recommendations to stay at home on the CDC's "Travel During COVID-19" site (link to archive from Apr 1 below):      https://web.archive.org/web/20210401020716/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: As of April 27th, the eviction moratorium is still in place.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210424154911/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf
notes_H1: The state department of health continues to urge people to wear masks and exercise caution with social distancing measures   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502234759/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/frequently-asked-questions-covid-19
notes_H2: Testing locations are available throughout the state with many free options through the state department of health  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502234645/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/covid-19-testing-locations
notes_H3: "South Carolinians are asking what they can to do stop the spread of COVID-19. Our response – answer the call. If you receive a call from 803-529-1551, please answer. This is a call from a contact monitor and answering will keep your loved ones and community safe through a process called contact tracing. All information collected by DHEC’s trained contact tracers is voluntary, confidential and over the phone."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210421113409/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/covid-19-contact-tracing
notes_H6: Mask required in certain counties.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210421113729/https://scemd.maps.arcgis.com/apps/dashboards/56fe19fc19fb4654af158685f56336c5
notes_H7: "Currently, all South Carolinians age 16 and older can get their COVID-19 vaccine.    South Carolina's phased approach to its COVID-19 vaccine rollout was focused on saving lives, which is why those most at risk for severe illness and death were prioritized to receive vaccine first. With more and more vaccine becoming available and more and more people receiving their shots, South Carolina is now able to open vaccines to anyone 16 and older."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210421113957/https://scdhec.gov/covid19/covid-19-vaccine

notes_C1: As of April 26th, there were no more school closures. On April 13th, the Tennessee Board of Education dictated that students had to return to school for in-person learning. notes_C2: This week, Nashville entered phase 4 of its reopening plans. Bars and restaurants were allowed to host up to 225 people per floor. Self-served establishments were now allowed to open. Gyms, entertainment facilities, camps, museums, and personal care services were allowed to open. All businesses that decided to open had to strictly follow Covid-19 protocols.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210502130639/https://www.asafenashville.org/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502131046/https://www.asafenashville.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Order-14-Modified-Phase-Four-Reopening.pdf
notes_C3: This week, Nashville entered phase 4 of its reopening plans. notes_H6: On April 27th, Governor Bill Lee issued EO-80, requiring health departments across Tennessee to rescind their mask mandate by May 30th. Following these announcements, several cities and counties, such as Davidson and Knox counties, decided to keep their public mask mandate. In Davidson county, people were required to wear a mask indoors. In Knox county, the board of education kept the school mask mandate. notes_H7: 13 April: Like other states, Tennessee is pausing use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine over fears of blood clotting risk.     Read local news coverage of the Tennessee Department of Health's decision here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210419212055/https://www.wrcbtv.com/story/43661733/tennessee-joins-other-states-in-pausing-johnson-and-johnson-covid19-vaccine

name: Texas
notes_C1: As of May 3, 2021 there are still no changes to school closures.  Texas schools still have freedom to decide whether or not to follow the Texas Education Agency (TEA) released guidelines based on the new executive order GA 34.     Most Texas school districts remain open, but also offer virtual learning. Many continue to provide daily, on-campus learning for any family who wants it in order to not lose state funding due to declines in enrollment. School districts can require individual students who are falling behind academically to return to in-person classes.    Mostly all Texas Universities have chosen to keep COVID-19 policies in place, even though Governor Abbott ended the mask mandate (March 10th, 2021). While some schools continue with complete virtual learning for spring semester, others continue hybrid learning. Texas A&M continues their mandatory testing program for students.    Links:    School Closure Map by State:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503210407/https://www.edweek.org/leadership/map-where-are-schools-closed/2020/07       Texas Education Agency (TEA) Guidance Link and Press Release Update:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210327074522/https://tea.texas.gov/sites/default/files/covid/SY-20-21-Public-Health-Guidance.pdf     Texas University Updates:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503222346/https://www.tamu.edu/coronavirus/testing-locations/index.html     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503222427/https://www.kxan.com/texas-universities-and-schools-response-to-coronavirus/
notes_C2: As of May 3, 2021, the Health Authority Emergency Rules still apply to Austin and Travis counties. These will expire May 18, 2021. Guidelines require  at least 6 feet between groups of 10 or fewer and face coverings in establishments and businesses. As a result, coding remains 2T.    For the greater state of Texas, Executive Order GA34 is still in effect.  In all counties without high hospitalization, there are no COVID-19 related operation limits for any business or establishments (e.g., gyms, salons, restaurants, public and private schools, childcare services). Businesses can now operate at 100% occupancy, unless county judges use COVID related mitigation strategies-limited to no less than a 50% total occupancy.       Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210312014942/https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf     Austin/ Travis, Texas Guidelines:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419212756/https://www.kxan.com/news/local/austin/austin-public-health-provides-update-on-vaccine-guidance-extends-health-rules-through-may-18/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503222519/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules
notes_C3: As of May 3, 2021, the Health Authority Emergency Rules still apply to Austin and Travis counties. These will expire May 18, 2021. Gatherings are limited to 10 people or less.    For the greater state of Texas, Executive Order GA34 is still in effect. There are no evident executive state orders on the limit or restriction of public events.       Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210312014942/https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf     Austin/ Travis County Orders:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419212756/https://www.kxan.com/news/local/austin/austin-public-health-provides-update-on-vaccine-guidance-extends-health-rules-through-may-18/     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503222519/https://www.austintexas.gov/department/covid-19-information/orders-rules     https://web.archive.org/web/20210416183108/https://www.austintexas.gov/sites/default/files/files/Health/Health-Authority-Rules-April-13-2021.pdf
notes_C4: As of May 3, 2021, the Health Authority Emergency Rules still apply to Austin and Travis counties. These will expire May 18, 2021. Gatherings are limited to 10 people or less and socializing in groups of 10+ individuals outside of the same household is prohibited.    On a state level, Executive Order GA34 remains in effect.  There are no evident executive state orders on the limit or restriction on gatherings. However, individuals are strongly encouraged (not required) to wear face coverings when it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distancing from another person not in the same household, based on unvaccinated status. For this reason coding remains 1G.    links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210312014942/https://open.texas.gov/uploads/files/organization/opentexas/EO-GA-34-opening-Texas-response-to-COVID-disaster-IMAGE-03-02-2021.pdf     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503222751/https://www.austintexas.gov/page/covid-19-risk-based-guidelines     Austin/ Travis County Orders:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419213018/https://www.traviscountytx.gov/news/2020/1945-novel-coronavirus-covid-19-information     https://web.archive.org/web/20210317161401/https://www.austintexas.gov/sites/default/files/files/Health/Risk%20Based%20Guidance%20V2%20-%20DRAFT%2016.pdf

notes_E1: As of May 3, 2021, the Texas Rent Relief Program continues (Launched Feb.15, 2021). The program provides monetary assistance to households in paying rent or utilities, Qualifying households can make no more than 80% of an area’s median income. Priority will be given to households making less than 50% of an areas median income or household members unemployed for at least 90 days. notes_H1: As of May 3, 2021, up to date information on covid is still provided through social media (e.g., twitter) and the Texas government website.    Links:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503223102/https://www.texas.gov/covid19/     https://archive.vn/cYfUc
notes_H2: As of May 3, 2021, public screening and antibody collection sites are still available statewide- in person and at drive through locations. People with symptoms are encouraged to get tested, but symptoms are not required for a test.    General Testing Information Link:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503224155/https://www.dshs.state.tx.us/coronavirus/testing.aspx     Testing Location Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210503025832/https://tdem.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=1e91fb79fa44417898738e5bff31a3d8%2F

notes_H6: As of May 3, 2021, the Health Authority Emergency Rules still apply to Austin and Travis counties. These will expire May 18, 2021. Face coverings in establishments, businesses, and in public areas are required. Austin has clearance to enforce its own mandate, given court ruling (March 26 2021). As a result, coding remains 3T.    On a state level, Executive Order GA34 remains in effect.  All mask mandates have been removed. While individuals are no longer required by law to wear face coverings, individuals are strongly encouraged to wear face coverings when it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distancing from another person not in the same household (unvaccinated status). notes_H7: As of May 3, 2021 Texas eligibility for COVID-19 vaccination remains open to individuals aged 16+.     Moderna vaccine is being used for individuals 18 and older, while the Pfizer vaccine is authorized for people 16 and older. The Texas Health commissioner is now asking that sites now resume use of the  Johnson & Johnson/Janssen COVID-19 vaccine, after US health officials ended their vaccine halt (Friday April 23, 2021). name: Utah
notes_C1: General reopening with some restrictions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210424140749if_/https://schools.utah.gov/coronavirus?mid=4985&aid=3
notes_C2: There is now one county (Grand County) with a "high" rate of transmission. No closings are required, but distancing measures are in effect.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501171125/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C3: As per state guidance, public events in areas under high or moderate levels of COVID-19 transmission are required to enforce the use of face masks and 6ft distancing between parties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501171125/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C4: No longer recommended to limit gatherings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501171125/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_C5: No policy change.
notes_C6: No policy change.
notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: On March 30th, according to Ballotpedia, "President Joe Biden (D) signed a bill extending the deadline to apply for a forgivable loan through the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) from March 31 to May 31. The bill also extended the authorization period for new loans through June 30. The bill passed the House 415-3 and passed the Senate 92-7."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406153017/https://ballotpedia.org/Federal_government_responses_to_the_coronavirus_(COVID-19)_pandemic,_2020-2021
notes_E2: As of April 27th, the eviction moratorium is still in place.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210424154911/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf
notes_H1: Coordinated public information campaign continues.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501171125/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_H2: Testing available to those who are symptomatic and/or who made effective contact with someone who has COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210424142640/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/testing-locations/
notes_H3: Limited contact tracing efforts continue.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501171856/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/testing-locations/
notes_H6: Facial coverings are required by some businesses and public gatherings over 50 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501171125/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/utah-health-guidance-levels/
notes_H7: The Johnson & Johnson and Moderna vaccines are universally available to all Utahns 18+. The Pfizer vaccine is available for all 16+.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501172834/https://coronavirus.utah.gov/vaccine/

name: Virginia
notes_C1: As of 3 May 2021, according to the Department of Education's School Operational Status map, the state is currently divided between in-person, hybrid and remote teaching.    58 divisions are teaching in-person.  42 divisions are teaching partially in-person.  27 divisions are teaching in a hybrid format.  4 divisions are teaching partially in a hybrid format.  1 division is predominantly remote.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503145539/https://www.doe.virginia.gov/support/health_medical/office/reopen-status.shtml
notes_C2: As of 3 May 2021, no change has been detected.    All businesses may remain open subject to the sector-specific restrictions in the Guidelines for Businesses.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210503145319/https://www.virginia.gov/coronavirus/forwardvirginia/faq/?1
notes_C3: As of 3 May 2021, no change has been detected.    As of 3 May 2021, no change has been detected.    - Social gatherings are restricted to 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors.  - All indoor and outdoor entertainment and public amusement venues must continue to operate at 30 percent capacity. Indoor venues must operate at 30 percent capacity or with a maximum of 500 people, an increase from the current cap of 250 people. Outdoor venues must operate at 30 percent capacity, with no specific cap on the number of attendees. These venues were previously limited to 30 percent capacity or up to 1,000 attendees, whichever was fewer.   - Recreational sporting events: The number of spectators allowed at recreational sporting events will increase from 25 to 100 people per field or 30 percent capacity, whichever is less for indoor settings, and from 250 to 500 people per field or 30 percent capacity, whichever is less for outdoor settings.  - In-person graduation and commencement events: Governor Northam issued preliminary guidance on safe in-person graduations and commencements, which included a cap of 5,000 people or 30 percent of the venue capacity for outdoor events, whichever is less. Events held indoors may have up to 500 people, or 30 percent of the venue capacity, whichever is less. Attendees must wear masks and follow other guidelines and safety protocols to ensure proper distancing."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503144246/https://www.governor.virginia.gov/newsroom/all-releases/2021/march/headline-893995-en.html
