notes_E2: No change. Rent relief remains available in Virginia.    Additionally, the utility disconnections moratorium remains in effect, as laid out in House Bill 5005.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419050124/https://www.pwcgov.org/news/pages/Governor-Northam-Announces-Virginia-Rent-Relief-Program.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503140507/https://budget.lis.virginia.gov/get/budget/4283/HB5005/
notes_H1: As of 3 May 2021, Virginia's COVID-specific webpages remain updated and live.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503095456/https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/coronavirus/
notes_H2: As of 3 May 2021, no change has been detected for this indicator. The Virginia Department of Health recommends the following groups be tested:    - People with symptoms of COVID-19, regardless of their COVID-19 vaccination status  - People who have had close contact with someone with COVID-19   - People who have taken part in activities that put them at higher risk for COVID-19 because they cannot physically distance as needed, such as attending large gatherings or being in crowded settings  - People who are planning to travel or who have recently returned from travel with some exceptions for fully vaccinated people  - People who are planning to visit people at high risk of developing severe COVID-19  - People who live or work in congregate settings (e.g., long-term care facilities, correctional facilities, homeless shelters, crowded workplaces)   - People who have been asked or referred to get testing by their healthcare provider or the health department  - People without symptoms of COVID-19 who have no known exposures to COVID-19 but wish to help public health officials understand how many people are infected (surveillance testing)     Hence, testing is available for asymptomatic and symptomatic individuals.    Testing is available across the state at a variety of locations, including at a healthcare provider’s office, urgent care center, pharmacy, other healthcare clinic, or community testing events.    Testing eligibility:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503094818/https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/coronavirus/covid-19-testing/    Testing sites:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503095152/https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/coronavirus/covid-19-testing/covid-19-testing-sites/
notes_H3: As of 3 May 2021, there has been no detected change for this indicator.    The Virginia Department of Health continues to report the following:   A large number of cases of COVID-19 are still reported daily across Virginia. Health departments in Virginia that are unable to perform timely follow-up of all cases and tracing of their close contacts may need to prioritize certain contact tracing and case investigations based on CDC guidance.    As a result, continuing to code as 1.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503094311/https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/coronavirus/prevention-tips/contact-tracing/
notes_H6: As of 3 May 2021, the following requirements remain in place with regard to facial coverings:    - All people aged 5 and older must cover both their mouth and nose with a mask in indoor settings with others. This does not apply to people who live in the same home.  - All people aged 5 and older must cover their mouth and nose with a mask when they are outdoors and cannot stay at least 6 feet away from others who do not live with them.  - Masks for Children: Adults should use their best judgement in putting face masks on children ages 2-4 while inside public areas or when outdoors and within 6 feet of others who do not live with them. Masks should not be worn by children under the age of 2 years. For children aged 2 years or older, find a mask made for children, if you are able to.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503093923/https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/coronavirus/cloth-face-covers/
notes_H7: As of 3 May 2021, all Virginians above the age 16 are eligible for vaccination.    Virginia is receiving weekly shipments of the Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson vaccines from the federal government.    Vaccine eligibility:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503092755/https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/covid-19-vaccine/    FAQ including vaccine types:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503093319/https://www.vdh.virginia.gov/covid-19-faq/vaccination/

name: Vermont
notes_C1: As of 26 April 2021, the latest data from the Strong Health and Schools Survey Dashboard shows that schools are still not completely opened or closed.     12% of schools are fully remote, 32% are in-person, 55% hybrid. There is a flexible policy depending on school.    Continuing to code as 2T, as neither universities nor schools are completely open for in-person teaching.     Dashboard:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426182639/https://education.vermont.gov/news/covid-19-guidance-vermont-schools/strong-and-healthy-schools-survey-information
notes_C2: Effective 9 April, as laid out in the Vermont Forward plan, universal guidance will transition businesses from sector-specific mitigation measures to more broad mitigation measures across most sectors.    No workplace closures have been outlined.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426174749/https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19/vermont-forward/business-operations
notes_C3: As of 26 April 2021, all event venues; arts, culture, and entertainment venues; restaurants; bars; and clubs serving the public shall suspend public or private social, recreational and entertainment gatherings, indoor and outdoor, including large social gatherings incidental to ceremonies, holiday gatherings, parties and celebrations, unless all participants are from the same household.    Additionally, Vermont has restrictions on social gatherings based on whether you are fully vaccinated or not. You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot. Since children cannot get vaccinated at this time, a household with children is not considered a fully vaccinated household.   If you are fully vaccinated:  -You may gather with other fully vaccinated people or households.   -You may gather with up to two unvaccinated people or households at a time. The gathering can also include other vaccinated people or households.  If you are not fully vaccinated:  -You may gather with fully vaccinated people or households.  -You may gather with one other unvaccinated person or household at a time.  -You can do outdoor recreation and fitness activities with anyone.     Public event restrictions:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426174749/https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19/vermont-forward/business-operations    Gathering restrictions FAQ:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426175429/https://apps.health.vermont.gov/COVID/faq/
notes_C4: As of 26 April 2021, limitations on household gatherings remain in place in Vermont.    Vermont has restrictions on social gatherings based on whether you are fully vaccinated or not. You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot. Since children cannot get vaccinated at this time, a household with children is not considered a fully vaccinated household.     If you are fully vaccinated:  -You may gather with other fully vaccinated people or households.   -You may gather with up to two unvaccinated people or households at a time. The gathering can also include other vaccinated people or households.    If you are not fully vaccinated:  -You may gather with fully vaccinated people or households.  -You may gather with one other unvaccinated person or household at a time.  -You can do outdoor recreation and fitness activities with anyone.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210426175429/https://apps.health.vermont.gov/COVID/faq/
notes_C5: As of 26 April 2021, there has been no detected change in the closure of public transport in Vermont. Continuing to code as 0.    No evidence has been found to suggest that the delivery of these services has been altered, aside from requirements for social distancing and/or wearing face coverings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426180310/https://vpta.net/
notes_C6: As of 9 April 2021, as laid out in the Vermont Forward Plan, businesses are no longer encouraged to use telework and remote work as much as possible. However, continuing to code as 1G, due to current restrictions on gatherings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426174749/https://accd.vermont.gov/covid-19/vermont-forward/business-operations
notes_C7: Effective 9 April 2021, there is new travel guidance in Vermont.    Unvaccinated people must have a COVID-19 test within 3 days before arriving in Vermont.  - The test must be for a current infection (like a PCR test), except it cannot be an antigen test (also known as a rapid test).  - Proof must be presented of a negative test result.  - Quarantining does not exempt individuals from the testing requirement. They may choose to quarantine, but are still required to get a negative test before coming to Vermont.  - Vaccinated people do not need to get tested.    People who have recovered from COVID-19 within the last 3 months do not need to test unless they develop new symptoms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426172918/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/travel-quarantine/visitors-vermont
notes_C8: As of April 27th, the CDC states:   "With specific exceptions, several Presidential proclamations suspend and limit entry into the United States, as immigrants or nonimmigrants, of noncitizens who were physically present within the following countries during the 14-day period preceding their entry or attempted entry into the United States." This includes fully vaccinated people.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426160314/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426010332/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/international-travel-during-covid19.html
notes_E1: As of 26 April 2021, unemployment benefits are still available for individuals who are forced to leave their employment for a COVID-19 qualifying reason (as stated in Addendum 13 to EO 01-20).    Additionally, Bill H.742, which expands unemployment eligibility provisions for workers and offers relief to employers affected by the coronavirus pandemic, remains in effect.    H.742:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426172020/https://legislature.vermont.gov/bill/status/2020/H.742    Addendum 13 to EO 01-20:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426172355/https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%2013%20TO%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20_1.pdf
notes_E2: On 26 April, the temporary moratorium of natural gas, electric, and traditional landline telephone service remains in effect. This will expire on May 31, 2021, unless extended.    Additionally, S.333 remains in effect. This prohibits evictions until 30 days after the termination of the state of emergency.    Order extending the utility disconnection moratorium:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426171543/https://documentcloud.adobe.com/link/track?uri=urn%3Aaaid%3Ascds%3AUS%3A73cb866e-627b-4bd0-b0ec-ee235c821509    S.333:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426171646/https://legislature.vermont.gov/bill/status/2020/S.333
notes_H1: As of 26 April 2021, Vermont's COVID-19 website remains live.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426171206/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19
notes_H2: As of 26 April 2021, COVID-19 testing remains to be generally available across Vermont.     There are a large number of testing sites across the state, these are available on an open public testing basis.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426171007/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/testing/where-get-tested
notes_H3: No evidence found to suggest that contact tracing is no longer comprehensive in Vermont - the DOH website, press releases, news articles and executive orders have been searched. Continuing to code as 2.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210425214714/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/symptoms-sickness/close-contacts-contact-tracing
notes_H6: As of 25 April 2021, face coverings are still required in all public spaces in Vermont.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210425214245/https://apps.health.vermont.gov/COVID/faq/
notes_H7: As of 20 April 2021, all people 16 and older can get the vaccine. Johnson & Johnson have been canceled while Moderna and Pfizer are still being distributed.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210420033638/https://www.healthvermont.gov/covid-19/vaccine/getting-covid-19-vaccine

name: Washington
notes_C1: Every school district is still operating a version of hybrid teaching (both in-person and online) except for Kent school district.  Kent county is 100% remote and the only college in Kent, the Kent location of the Green River Community College is also only remote.   Given that the every level in Kent is remote, the coding has been changed to 3T from 2T.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329195914/https://www.k12.wa.us/about-ospi/press-releases/novel-coronavirus-covid-19-guidance-resources/school-reopening-data    https://web.archive.org/web/20210408191707/https://www.greenriver.edu/campus/campus-safety/emergency-preparedness/covid19/
notes_C2: All counties remain in Phase 3 of the Roadmap to Recovery plan. Most sectors are able to operate at reduced capacity, remote work is "strongly encouraged" for professional services. For more detailed information, visit archived link.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329201727/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/safe-start/whats-open
notes_C3: Although restrictions on residential/private gatherings are still in place (10 indoor, 50 outdoor) in Phase 3 of Washington's Recovery Plan, Phase 3 allows up to 50% occupancy or 400 people maximum, whichever is lower, for all indoor spaces. This applies to all industries and indoor activities currently allowed; restaurants, gyms and fitness centers and movie theaters, among others.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329200916/https://medium.com/wagovernor/inslee-announces-statewide-move-to-phase-3-of-recovery-plan-return-to-spectator-events-and-tier-2-4a53000f2724
notes_C4: Phase 3 of Healthy Washington: Roadmap to Recovery is in place for all counties in Washington. Limit of 10 people may gather indoors. Limit of 50 may gather outside.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329201727/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/safe-start/whats-open
notes_C5: Sound Transit (a large regional transit system) is tracking ridership and will adjust bus and train service in order to meet demand and allow passengers to ride safely.     King County Metro is operating on reduced service, though it sites budget constraints, not Covid-19, as the reason.     Pierce Transit is offering reduced service to maintain safety and adequate cleaning.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329203341/https://kingcounty.gov/depts/transportation/metro/schedules-maps/healthier-metro.aspx    Sound transit: https://archive.vn/EHUXv    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329203302/https://www.piercetransit.org/
notes_C6: Staying at home and continuing to practice physical distancing is encouraged.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210329204617/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/stay-home-stay-healthy
notes_C7: On April 6th, the governor of Washington updated his guidelines for both interstate and international travel:   "Gov. Jay Inslee today updated Proclamation 20-83 to clarify that, in addition to requiring compliance with CDC restrictions related to international flight travel, all other types of travel, including intrastate travel, should also follow CDC guidance and requirements"    and that:   ", I hereby prohibit any individual from  traveling by air from any location outside of the United States to Washington state, directly  or indirectly, unless that individual complies with the requirements established by the CDC  that can be found at this website. Individuals exempted from the CDC requirements are also  exempt from this proclamation...I issued a travel advisory on November 13, 2020, recommending that  travelers avoid non-essential travel and self-quarantine upon arriving in Washington from  out of state. I rescinded that travel advisory on March 19, 2021, and instead recommended  that travelers follow the CDC’s COVID-19 travel guidance."    See archives:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210407083340/governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-updates-travel-restriction-proclamation    https://web.archive.org/web/20210413094244/https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-83.2.pdf
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: "Gov. Jay Inslee today announced applications will be accepted for the next round of assistance under the Washington COVID-19 Immigrant Relief Fund starting April 21.    The additional $65 million allocated by the Legislature this year will provide additional relief to support new applicants. Similar to the first round, the fund will rely on the continued partnership between the state and community organizations, including Scholarship Junkies and the Washington Immigrant Solidarity Network, with the Department of Social and Health Services providing oversight.     This round of funding builds on the governor’s prior allocations totaling $62.6 million for COVID-19 relief to immigrants in 2020, which provided much-needed assistance to nearly 60,000 individuals who were not eligible for federal COVID assistance due to immigration status. The fund coincides with other relief commitments by the governor in small business grants and rental assistance."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210427184128/https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/washington-covid-19-immigrant-relief-fund-opens-new-applications
notes_E2: "Insurance Commissioner Mike Kreidler extended his emergency order directing all state-regulated health insurers to make additional coverage changes to aid consumers during the coronavirus pandemic. His order is in effect until May 30 and requires health insurers to:        Continue coverage for providing telehealth via methods including telephone and video chat tools such as Facetime, Facebook Messenger video chat, Google Hangout video, Skype and Go-to-Meeting.       Treat drive-up testing sites for COVID-19 as provider visits with no copay, coinsurance or deductible.    All medically necessary diagnostic testing for flu and certain other viral respiratory illnesses billed during a provider visit for COVID-19 will now be subject to coinsurance and deductibles starting May 2.     To help free up hospital beds, Kreidler is directing health insurers to waive or expedite prior authorization requirements for home health care or long-term care facility services to speed up discharging patients who are ready to leave."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210502015810/https://www.insurance.wa.gov/news/kreidler-extends-emergency-order-telehealth-coverage-0
notes_H1: The state continues to share information and provides a toolkit to "spread the facts" about Covid-19. https://web.archive.org/web/20210329224017/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/partner-toolkit
notes_H2: Testing is widely available for anyone who would like to be tested.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210315160056/https://www.doh.wa.gov/Emergencies/COVID19/TestingforCOVID19
notes_H3: DOH centralized investigation targets for the timeliness of case investigation & contact tracing are:  • 90% of cases will be reached within 1 day of DOH receiving a positive test result  • 80% of contacts be reached within 2 days of DOH receiving a positive test result for the case    Washington's most recent data (March 7-13) shows they reached 52% of case investigations within one day (total percentage interviewed: 65%), and reached 72% of traced contacts within 2 days (for a total percentage of contacts interviewed at 82%).     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329231520/https://www.doh.wa.gov/Portals/1/Documents/1600/coronavirus/data-tables/COVID19-CaseInvestigationContractTracingReport.pdf
notes_H6: Masks continue to be required outside of the home. For more information:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210329233757/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/information-for/you-and-your-family/face-masks-or-cloth-face-covering
notes_H7: Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson    "The Washington State Department of Health (DOH) is adjusting the way COVID-19 vaccines are allocated in an effort to quickly and equitably reach more people statewide and get vaccine where it’s needed most.    Until recently, DOH used a pro-rata approach for allocations, which means doses were allocated to counties proportionally to match the size of their populations. As vaccine supply has increased, the number of doses health care providers are requesting doesn’t always align with county pro-rata allocations. Moving forward, DOH will make allocation decisions based on individual provider requests for vaccine, in addition to population size. Transitioning to this allocation model moves us closer into alignment with our existing childhood and adult vaccine programs, which are both based on provider request. We will continue to work closely with partners to ensure vaccine is available and accessible to everyone who lives or works in Washington state.    “While the pro-rata driven model worked well for the first few months of vaccine distribution, now that nearly 30% of Washingtonians are fully vaccinated, it is time to adjust our approach in support of our goals to vaccinate more Washingtonians as equitably, quickly, and efficiently as possible,” said Lacy Fehrenbach, Deputy Secretary of the COVID-19 response.    Each week, providers will continue to order the amount of vaccine they need and DOH will get weekly input from local health jurisdictions (LHJ) on community vaccine priorities. DOH will approve orders based on provider request and LHJ recommendations. Using this method, DOH will be able to distribute vaccine to the communities that need it most, while also providing extra doses to providers who continue to see higher need for vaccine.    In order to ensure providers across the state have doses available to vaccinate their community members, DOH is also offering flexibility to certain providers with throughput and usage. This includes providers who serve smaller communities, support equity efforts, and/or reach special populations, such as hospitals that transfer patients to long-term care facilities. We want to make sure vaccine is available to these groups when they need it."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210502015758/https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/vaccine-allocation-strategy-moving-provider-need-based-approach

name: Wisconsin
notes_C1: As of the 8th of March, many schools districts have schools that are operating remote, partially remote or in-person teaching. For example, the Milwaukee Public Schools district is planning a phased reopening for in-person learning with Pre-K through grade 2 will beginning on April 12, 2021, students in grades 3 through 8 will begin April 19, 2021, and students in grades 9 through 12 will begin April 26, 2021. The Elmbrook School District offers both virtual and in-person learning options for students.     Sources:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308105104/https://mps.milwaukee.k12.wi.us/en/District/Superintendent/Blog/Roadmap-to-Readiness-Update-January-2021.htm    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308105626/https://www.elmbrookschools.org/community/learninghub
notes_C2: On the 8th of March, Executive Order 105 that was issued by Governor Evers remains in place. The order declares a state of public health emergency in response to the spread of the coronavirus throughout Wisconsin. This maintains that people should stay at home as much as possible.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301135200/https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/EO/EO105-PHE.pdf
notes_C3: As of 8 March, Executive order 105 is still in place declaring a public health emergency specifically related to the new B.1.1.7 variant. This order urges people to stay at home as much as possible.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301135200/https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/EO/EO105-PHE.pdf
notes_C4: Madison and Dane County Emergency Order #15 does not make any changes to the policy outlined in Order #14 with regard to this indicator. See note on 10 March 2021 for more details on Order #14.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404151757/https://publichealthmdc.com/documents/2021-04-02_Order_15.pdf
notes_C5: The Wisconsin department of health services states that "COVID-19 case patients and close contacts are prohibited from using public transportation (for example, airplane, bus, ship, shuttle) during their isolation or quarantine periods." The City of Madison is also reducing their capacity  on all Metro Transit fixed-route buses to 20 passengers plus the driver.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201222535/https://www.cityofmadison.com/metro/contact/covid-19-updates    https://web.archive.org/web/20210224190929/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/travel.htm
notes_C6: As of 8 March, Executive order 105 is still in place declaring a public health emergency specifically related to the new B.1.1.7 variant. This order urges people to stay at home as much as possible to prevent the spread of the new variant.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301135200/https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/EO/EO105-PHE.pdf
notes_C7: As of 8 March, Executive order 105 is still in place declaring a public health emergency specifically related to the new B.1.1.7 variant. This order urges people to stay at home as much as possible to prevent the spread of the new variant.     The DHS also recommends that people should cancel or postpone internal travel.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301135200/https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/EO/EO105-PHE.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210224190929/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/travel.htm
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: As of December 1st, the Department of Workforce Development still detailed unemployment benefits, as well as several extensions to benefits due to the pandemic.     See archive:   http://web.archive.org/web/20201201011650/https://dwd.wisconsin.gov/covid19/public/ui.htm#collapse1-23
notes_E2: As of February 1, 2021, the annual winter moratorium on utilities, which lasts until April 15, 2021, is still in effect. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201029025941/https://apps.psc.wi.gov/APPS/NewsReleases/content/PDF_download.aspx?id=663
notes_H1: As of 8 March, the Wisconsin Department of Health Services is still operating a coordinated public health information campaign.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210304145019/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/index.htm
notes_H2: As of 8 March, testing is still generally available through primary care providers, community testing sites and at home specimen kits (at no cost to Wisconsinites).    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210220021543/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/testing.htm
notes_H3: As of 8 March, a comprehensive contact tracing system remains in place.     Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301144135/https://www.dhs.wisconsin.gov/covid-19/contact-tracing.htm
notes_H6: On March 31st, the Wisconsin Supreme Court overturned the statewide mask mandate in a 4-3 vote. In this ruling, the WI Supreme Court blocked Gov. Evers from issuing any new mask mandates without the approval of the state legislature. However, there are still mask mandates in some cities throughout the state. As such, the coding switches from 3G to 3T.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405031351/https://www.jsonline.com/story/communities/lake-country/news/2021/04/02/wisconsin-schools-still-require-masks-despite-revoked-statewide-order/4836216001/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210407230612/https://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/2021/03/31/supreme-court-blocks-tony-evers-extending-covid-mask-mandate/7060433002/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210409011026/https://www.tmj4.com/news/coronavirus/these-are-the-mask-orders-still-in-effect-in-se-wisconsin-and-when-they-expire
notes_H7: As of April 5, 2021, anyone age 16 and over will be eligible for the vaccine (Pfizer, Moderna).     Use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine was paused on April 14, 2021.    Sources:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405221755/https://content.govdelivery.com/accounts/WIGOV/bulletins/2ca3d5f  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405222516/https://www.channel3000.com/everyone-16-and-older-is-now-eligible-for-the-covid-vaccine-in-wisconsin/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419203559/https://pbswisconsin.org/news-item/wisconsins-covid-condition-pause-on-johnson-johnson-doses-complicates-vaccination-campaign-at-critical-juncture/"

name: West Virginia
notes_C1: As of March 24, 2021, “All West Virginia private and public schools, including elementary, middle/junior high schools, and high schools, may be open for in-person instruction and/or extracurricular activities without regard to the designation of the school's county on the DHHR County Alert System, provided that such schools or school systems should coordinate with their local health departments to manage any limitations on in-person instruction that may be advised from time to time by such local health departments,” according to the website of the Governor of West Virginia. There is no change in policy, so this remains coded as 1G.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427205619/https://governor.wv.gov/The-Comeback/Pages/default.aspx
notes_C2: As of April 27th, the CDC recommendations include risk mitigation but does not recommend closures. The "Guidance for Businesses and Employers Responding to Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)" was last updated on December 31st, 2020 and also doesn't recommend closures.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210426140506/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/organizations/business-employers/bars-restaurants.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426042602/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/guidance-business-response.html
notes_C3: As of April 27, there has been no policy change. Though some events such as live music festivals can now resume, "all fairs, festivals, and summer camps may resume operations from May 1, 2021, provided that all such events follow all applicable safety guidelines."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210427205619/https://governor.wv.gov/The-Comeback/Pages/default.aspx
notes_C4: As of April 19, 2021, “the limit for all purely social gatherings has been lifted,” according to the website of the Governor of West Virginia. Therefore, this policy has been downgraded to 0.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210427205619/https://governor.wv.gov/The-Comeback/Pages/default.aspx
notes_C5: As of April 27, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_C6: As of April 27, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_C7: As of April 27, 2021, there has been no policy change.
notes_C8: On April 30th, the US government updates their banned country list to include India.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210430045243/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
notes_E1: 19 April: Governor Justice signed a new executive order cleaning up COVID-19 regulations and abolishing a lot of previous orders. In this new order, he reinstated some requirements for unemployment benefits. Previously, an executive order had made it easier to access unemployment benefits during the pandemic. As the press release notes:   “This [new] order will also reinstate some requirements for unemployment benefits that we waived early on during the pandemic,” Gov. Justice said. “We need to put these requirements back so we can get back to work." This new order's unemployment provisions will not go into effect until 1 June, so the code remains unchanged.      Read more here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210427214641/https://governor.wv.gov/News/press-releases/2021/Pages/COVID-19-UPDATE-Gov-Justice-issues-executive-order-updating-and-clarifying-several-COVID-19-regulations.aspx
notes_E2: As of April 27th, the eviction moratorium is still in place.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210424154911/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/pdf/CDC-Eviction-Moratorium-03292021.pdf
notes_H1: As of April 27, 2021, there has been no change in policy.
notes_H2: As of April 27, 2021, there has been no change in policy.
notes_H3: As of April 27, 2021, there has been no change in policy.
notes_H6: As of April 19, 2021, “All West Virginians age 9 and older are required to wear a face covering at all times inside all indoor public places. The requirement does not apply to anyone who has trouble breathing or anyone who is otherwise unable to remove their own face covering without assistance. It also does not apply to anyone inside a restaurant and actively consuming food or beverages, anyone is inside a closed room by themselves, or inside one’s residence . . . if you are actively engaged in physical activity like indoor sports, you do not need to wear a face covering,” according to the website of the Governor of West Virginia. Because of the new exemption for indoor exercise, this policy has been downgraded to 2G.    Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427205619/https://governor.wv.gov/The-Comeback/Pages/default.aspx
notes_H7: On April 30, 2021, Governor Justice announced that all West Virginians ages 16-35 who have already been vaccinated or will be vaccinated will receive a $100 savings bond incentive.    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503183417/https://www.npr.org/2021/04/30/992545248/west-virginia-governor-discusses-his-100-offer-to-young-people-who-get-vaccinate

notes_C1: No new updates as of 30 April 2021. https://archive.vn/qZWlA    Live link: https://www.tcsd.org/News/193#sthash.Kfhb8EMb.w6L3vWmq.dpbs

notes_C7: As of April 27th, the CDC details:  "CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19. If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, follow CDC’s recommendations for unvaccinated people."  And:    "If you are not fully vaccinated and must travel, take the following steps to protect yourself and others from COVID-19  Before you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 1-3 days before your trip.  While you are traveling:  Wear a mask over your nose and mouth. Masks are required on planes, buses, trains, and other forms of public transportation traveling into, within, or out of the United States and in U.S. transportation hubs such as airports and stations.  Avoid crowds and stay at least 6 feet/2 meters (about 2 arm lengths) from anyone who is not traveling with you.  Wash your hands often or use hand sanitizer (with at least 60% alcohol).  After you travel:  Get tested with a viral test 3-5 days after travel AND stay home and self-quarantine for a full 7 days after travel.  Even if you test negative, stay home and self-quarantine for the full 7 days" when travelling domestically and includes requirements for testing, but doesn't state any restrictions.     See archive:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210427024830/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html
